results.description:
Welcome to our regular meetup!  We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing board games -- specifically, the kind of board games that make you think.  We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.

This season, in addition to playing games, we will be raffling off a bunch of popular games!  There will be raffles at each meetup. Simply by showing up, you'll get a chance to win free games. The more often you come, the more entries you'll receive.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message ahead of time, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm until 11:00 pm or later.

Our group has been running since 2007, and at this point we have a pretty large crowd of regulars.  A lot of people come once every few weeks, and RSVPs are appreciated but not required, so the RSVP list is often smaller than our actual attendance.  We expect about 30-45 people at most of our meetups.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

People new to Euros are very welcome.  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); the heaviest strategy games (like 18xx or wargames); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (You will also receive extra raffle tickets any time you donate.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

results.description: Hi all! For this second meetup, the tentative plan is to repeat the approximately 2.5 mile loop from the first, which begins in front of the East Boston branch of the Boston Public Library, centrally located at 365 Bremen St. We will utilize the car-free paths of the Bremen Street Park, go onto the Greenway, and make a loop at the East Piers Park eventually making our way back to the library. Of course, everyone should run at their pace, but at the same time faster EBRunners should strive to provide company to the less experienced EBRunners so nobody is running alone for long stretches. Let's hope the weather cooperates, but there is no plan to cancel in the event of a little rain. Please, please make sure running is a safe activity for you before participating. With that said, I look forward to seeing you! Happy Running, Ilya
results.name: Cruising Altitude

results.description:
Qi Gong is a conscious meditation, which is energy movement that stimulates self-healing and balance for the body’s systems. “Qi” is energy and “Gong” is movement. By connecting breath, intention, and action, you strengthen your core and bring balance to your body, mind, and soul. The journey promises to be prayerful, electric, and playful with the destination being one of peace and empowerment. Godfrey is well loved and circles the country to bring his fun and profound Qi Gong program to hundreds of grateful followers.


Rsvp with Godfrey:[masked]
(Godfrey is also teaching this class on August 19)

results.description:
<a href="http://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/quotes/c/confucius122071.html?src=t_silence"></a>"Silence is a true friend who never betrays. - Confucius

It's easy to fill every moment of every day.  When is it that Silence is needed to break the noise?  What is the value of contemplation and listening?   What are reasons to resist silence?  What are the risks?  Can listening or learning for that matter happen outside of silence?

"We need to find God, and he cannot be found in noise and restlessness. God is the friend of silence. See how nature - trees, flowers, grass- grows in silence; see the stars, the moon and the sun, how they move in silence... We need silence to be able to touch souls. - Mother Teresa


Here's an interesting article on silence: http://nautil.us/issue/16/nothingness/this-is-your-brain-on-silence, about the success of noise cancelling headphones, Daniel Gross writes, "In a loud world, Silence Sells."

Sorry again for the last-minute Meet-up! We're working on Summer Time :).
results.how_to_find_us: ask the hostess
results.name: On Silence

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
JP Comics & Games in Jamaica Plain is now running a table for players interested in the newly-begun season of D&D 5e weekly Encounters every Wednesday from 7-9.

"Unearth the Deception" and help stop the forces of Elemental Evil from plunging the Sword Coast into chaos. Designed to take players from level 1 to level 5 by the time the season ends in August, this is a great way to (re)introduce yourself to D&D's current edition and get immersed in a storyline that harks back to the origins of the game.

Pre-generated characters are available, as is help to build your own, so feel free to drop in or contact Ted Atkinson if you'd like more information.

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

This group is for people with some basic Astrology knowledge and is learning at a beginner/advanced beginner level. Please bring your birth chart if you have one, or give your birth information when you register.

This class sets its own agenda dealing with current events, current planetary placement such as lunar cycles or retrograde planets. Discussions are centered on these factors and how they impact us on a more personal level as individuals.

Over the first few months of 2014 we will be going over the house one at a time in depth.

Come on by and join the fun!

If you need a fresh chart or don't have one and you plan to come please contact me, Dorothy at [masked] with your birth information and I will happily bring one to the meeting.

Namaste'

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

It is open to everyone. Starting times are 7:30pm during the fall and winter, and 8:30pm during the spring and summer. The program lasts about an hour.

Weather

The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here.

Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

>>> Tickets <<<

Public Open Nights are open to everyone, however space is limited. To reserve a ticket for admission click this link which will take you to our Eventbrite page.  [see website]

Location

The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Ave. in Boston, right above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell to the Observatory is on the fifth floor right next to room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.
Information

For information, please call[masked]-2630.

The Public Open Night at the Observatory is held clear Wednesday nights from 8:30 – 9:30pm. Call[masked] for the status.

Source: http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/
results.name: Public Open Night - Coit Observatory at Boston University

results.description:
** Walk down the driveway to the rear of the building; we have a private entrance at ground level. **

Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?
At TurnON, we play three communication games, and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created. TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you! It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of Orgasmic Meditation and information on where to learn more. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice (or touching anyone, or removing any clothing!).
$10, payable at the door.

**ALLOW AT LEAST AN EXTRA FIFTEEN MINUTES TO FIND PARKING! On-street meters are free after 8 PM, some are free after 6.**
results.name: TurnON Boston!

group.name: Cool Folks In the City -Young Adults - Get out the House!

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom Weekly Dance

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for Intermediate/Advanced Intermediate level players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike. If you'd like to play, please do the following: Click RSVP or send an email to Alan using the following URL:

http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=186541038

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters, and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well. The location for this volleyball meetup is at the JCC of the North Shore, 4 Community Road, Marblehead, MA[masked] | Home Page:

http://www.jccns.org/adult-volleyball/

This event is free if you are a member of JCC. If not, it's a one-time $10 membership fee that is valid for a day. As always, please remember: - Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP) - If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join. Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 8/12 Intermediate + Indoor Volleyball Marblehead JCC

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games, and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of Orgasmic Meditation and information on where to learn more. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice (or touching anyone, or removing any clothing!).

$10, payable at the door.

**ALLOW AT LEAST AN EXTRA FIFTEEN MINUTES TO FIND PARKING!**
results.how_to_find_us: Walk down the driveway to the rear of the building; we have a private entrance at ground level.

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: The field is right next to Alewife station on the Red Line. There is also plenty of parking provided no one else is using the field. (Not an issue in the winter.)

We will review some of the major steps of MBA applications as well as timing for each. We will also discuss tips and tricks as well as pitfalls to avoid. At the end, you will have the opportunity to ask any questions you have on the application process. **If you have any questions, you can ask them live or email them to Scott prior to the session**. Click below to access the webinar https://plus.google.com/events/cs2tgv6s3rdgbpub46lm1lf30s4

About Personal MBA Coach:

An MIT and Wharton MBA graduate, Scott Edinburgh founded Personal MBA Coach in 2008. With a boutique and personalized approach, Scott has helped hundreds of applicants get into top MBA programs around the world, including HBS, Stanford, Wharton, Columbia, Chicago Booth, MIT Sloan, London Business School, INSEAD, Kellogg, Tuck and many more.

Scott Edinburgh

results.description:
Darkroom Gallery in Essex Junction, VT is calling for nighttime imagery that conveys mystery, surrealism, isolation, loneliness, and time/timelessness.

Nighttime photography: delve into the darkest hours to uncover secrets and mysteries.   Photographers have long embraced the literary and artistic tradition of the night as theme and subject in their work. The romantic notions and sense of mystery associated with the night, and the transformation from the mundane world to the unknown provide ample material for photographers to explore through their work.

Tim Baskerville, founder of the night photography organization The Nocturnes has said, "Surrealism, the mystery of place, solitude, and a heightened sense of the nature of things - night photography seems a worthy vehicle, a ritual to express these themes.” 

Our very own Lance Keimig will jury this show and states, " The night holds secrets- secrets that may engage our curiosity, shelter us, or frighten us. There are those who seek comfort in the night and those who recoil from it.  Brave was the ancestor who stepped outside of the fire circle for he might never return.  The interplay of light, shadow, and extremes of contrast heighten this uncertainty - and when the element of time is added in the form of long exposures, the Night Photograph is indeed a worthy vehicle to express these themes."

                                       (Conway Summit ©Lance Keimig)


• Exibit Calender (Subject to Change)

• Submissions Close: 12 August 15, Midnight


• EST Juror's Choices Announced: by 19 August 15

• On-Line Check-in Due: 28 August 15

• Work Receipt Deadline: 14 September 15

• Exhibit Opens: 17 September 15

• Artists' Reception:TBD

• Exhibit Closes: 11 October 15

results.description:
Join us again this Thursday morning before you head out to work for a guided meditation of Scripture in the Jesuit tradition of Lectio Divina (Sacred Reading). All faiths (or non-faiths) are welcome! Alice will be facilitating.


What is Lectio?

Lectio Divina is an ancient Christian practice of unhurried, contemplative meditation on a portion of Scripture following four basic movements: 

Lectio: a time of slow repeated reading of Scripture punctuated by the use of a bell or chime. 

Meditatio: A time of quiet reflection on God's words and presence. 

Oratio: A time of silent conversational intimacy with God. 

Contemplatio: A time of listening for God's words for us personally.

We hope you'll join us in this deeply enriching spiritual practice.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be sitting on a sheet in the grass across from Stony Brook station.
results.name: Lectio Divina Meditation (Sacred Reading)

Register at: http://ewebinars.com/webinar/?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default&memberid=9778&webid=jlppjxwrep

So You:

a. Just read a real estate investing book
b. Attended your first seminar
c. Watched a late night infomercial
d. Listened to a webinar

And You:

a. Were told real estate is the fastest way to make money
b. Are convinced that you will be able to leave the job that you hate within the next 2 weeks
c. Thought about or have already paid $20,000 for a coaching program

But You:

a. Don't know what to do next
b. Were told by someone that it would never work
c. Are losing your confidence rapidly

Don't be embarrassed. Every person that got into real estate that wasn't hand held by a family member and grew up in the business started out the same way. 90 percent or more of those who have gotten excited about real estate never ended up even trying. Thinking big, attracting money, and being in control of your own destiny sound good, especially when a polished salesperson is the one painting the picture. The reality is: Real Estate is a business and it is hard work. The only people who will tell you otherwise are trying to sell you something(seminar, a coaching program, a book, a subscription). That's the bad news.

The good news is that there are a ton of easy steps that you can take in order to start moving in the right direction without doing anything drastic. And, if you put in the work, the results will come. On this webinar, Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development, will discuss:

1. Why real estate is the toughest industry to get into
2. How it can be the best industry to be in once you have momentum
3. Steps that you can take this week to start your real estate career
4. The basics of wholesaling

5.  Our training program that allows you inside access to our exact marketing programs that you can use to find deals to wholesale

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions for the company. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has helped his team to acquire over 34 properties in the past 6 months including both fix and flip and buy and hold transactions.

To sign up, please go to:

http://ewebinars.com/webinar/?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default&memberid=9778&webid=jlppjxwrep<a href="https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/5474109221069365505"></a>

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
***********************

To join the August Tournament please just go through our Join Page:  http://TennisNorthEast.com/join
***********************


How does the TennisNorthEast Tournament Work?

Every Match Counts *NEW* for 2015

Tennis Tournament Basic Concept

 Our tournaments are a single elimination format with a consolation bracket. Meaning you are guaranteed at least 2 matches. This tournament format will not be played at a single location over a weekend instead players are given 7 to 10 days to play each round's match.

 Our tournaments will be mixed gender unless we have particularly strong female enrollment in a city. The tournaments will be singles based until we receive enough response to open it up for doubles. Players will be grouped in brackets with players no greater than .5 of their current TLN League Rating. Meaning Skilled - 3.0 players will be matched with other 3.0 players and at most with Competitive - 3.5 level players. Competitive - 3.5 level players could be grouped with Advanced - 4.0 players but will not have Elite 4.5 level players in their bracket.

Our Guarantee

 We need at least 6 players to make a tournament bracket. If we can NOT reach this criteria then we will refund your entry fee and give you the next tournament for no cost. Our hope is to run multiple skill level brackets for each tournament. We are NOT going to show early enrollment for the tournaments. Also the 7-day money back guarantee expires as soon as the tournament starts. Tournaments will not allow for late enrollment.

Leveling

 All tournament players will need to have played 4 league/season or tennis ladder legacy matches before they can enter into a tournament. Players will be entered into the tournament that associates with their TLN's Player Rating. If a player wants to participate in a second draw at a rating higher than their Player Rating they will be allowed too.

Your Schedule and Availability

 These tournaments will be kicked off on Thursday's giving the first round opponents two weekends to play the first match and then each following round will have a full week to play the match. Players need to be local for at least the first 3 weeks after kickoff. Players with 1-week work trips or week long vacations during the first 3 weeks shouldn't participate in the tournament.

Seedings

  The TennisNorthEast staff will seed 25% of the participants based veteran status (Most number of matches played in their career) with the program. If we have 8 players enrolled we'll seed the top 2 players, 16 players the top 4 players. The rest of the players will be randomly entered into the draw.

Consolation Bracket

 We will run a consolation bracket for the players who lost their first match. Seedings for the consolation bracket will be randomly selected by the TennisNorthEast staff. The winner of the consolation bracket will receive a $25 Tennis Warehouse Gift Card.

Where to Play?

  Because the seeding of the tournament is mainly randomize the higher seed will NOT have home court preference. The league strongly suggests you meet half-way to cut the commute in half for both players. We provide an extensive list of tennis courts that have user submitted ratings. If two players need guidance they can certainly email our staff for suggestions.

Playing Format

  The preferred playing format for tournaments should be 2 sets with a 3rd set tie-breaker or 2 out of 3 sets. If the two players can't agree the default format will be the 2 sets with a 3rd set tie-breaker. In NYC we will accept 10 game pro set results mainly due to court availability.

Target Audience

  This will be our most competitive format. The target audience is for the player who are good sports and love to play competitive matches.

Prize Pool

 The prize pool will be based upon enrollment in each bracket. A tournament can have multiple brackets. The tournament prize structure is based around our partner Tennis Warehouse (TW).

6 to 10 players: $50 TW Gift Card for the winner*, $25 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for Consolation bracket winner
11 to 16: $100 TW GC for the winner* + Trophy, $50 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for Consolation winner
17 to 24: $150 TW GC for the winner* + Trophy, $50 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for 3rd & 4th place, $50 TW GC for Consolation winner
25+: $200 TW GC for the winner* + Trophy, $100 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for 3rd and 4th place, $50 TW GC for Consolation winner

 All tournament champions will be receive an entry into the End of the Year National Tourneys at the champions discounted rate.

Cost to Participate

 The cost will be $19.95 per tournament except for the inaugural tournament which will be $19.95.

Join Today!!

So Join Today and we'd be happy to get you enrolled into the next tournament.
results.name: August Tournament

results.description:
I have run this event the past three years and it is so much fun, let's do it again. Let's see HELP! a Beatles Tribute Band at Castle Hill. Every Thursday night during the summer, Castle Hill on the Crane Estate in Ipswich offers great music and dancing under the stars on the Grand Allee. The concert starts at 7 p.m. and ends at 9 p.m. Gates open at 5 p.m. for picnicking. Beer and wine cannot be carried in, but can be purchased at the event. We will meet between 5:30 and 5:45 p.m. in the Shaw's parking lot on Route 1A in Beverly (near the entrance to Shaw's) and carpool over to the Crane Estate. At $30 a car, it would be great if we could get about 5 people per car to save on the entrance fee. See details below:

What: HELP! Beatles Tribute Band

When: Thursday, August 13, 2015. Concerts start at 7 p.m. and end at 9 p.m. Gates open at 5 p.m. for picnicking.

Note: Rain will cancel this event, so please check back for an update if the forecast calls for inclement weather.

Where: We will meet between 5:30 and 5:45 p.m. at Shaw's, Route 1A in Beverly, and carpool over to the Crane Estate.

Cost: The Trustees of Reservations Members: $20/car. Nonmembers: $30/car. (If a car has more than 6 passengers, each additional passenger will be charged $5.) Tickets available at the gate only.

Please help us keep Castle Hill clean by carrying out what you carry in. Thank you, and hope to see you there!

For more information, visit http://www.thetrustees.org/.
results.name: Thursday Night Picnic Concert at Castle Hill - HELP! Beatles Tribute Band

results.description:
Join us at Cafe Paradise for a night of strategy games. Paradise Cafe is across the street from the Dedham Community Theater.  We will be at the back of the restaurant. Please make sure you order a drink, meal, or pastry as a thank you for letting us play. You'll find an espresso bar, pastries, coffees and teas, panini sandwiches, soups and salads. Some of the games that you will find are:

7 Wonders,

Pandemic,

Fluxx,

Munchkin,

Zoolaretto,

and many more.

Feel free to bring any games that you would like to play. I hope to see you there.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

HOW TO GET THERE

Paradise Cafe offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a dinner or pastry and a game. Conveniently located in Dedham off of Rt 1 on High St.  Large lot with lots of FREE parking is located across from the restaurant.

 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
results.how_to_find_us: Look for friendly gamers in the back of the restaurant

From the north or south on Rte. 128 / 95: Take exit 17 and follow route 135 through Needham Center. Immediately after the center turn left on Marked Tree Road and follow it through a few intersections until you come to a "T" intersection on Central Avenue. Turn left, go 100 yards and turn left into the Needham Town Forest parking area. (A dirt road.)

This will be cross posted in the C.H.A.O.S. group.

Funk, soul, jazz improvisation, and the traditions of Cuban music are the sparkplugs that drive the Zahili Gonzaleez Zamora Project. Zahili Gonzalez Zamora, trained at Havana’s National Conservatory of Music, was playing classical music ten hours a day by age 14 and it was only after touring as a professional musician that she discovered her love for improvisation and jazz. Now the talented arranger and composer, expanding her musical prowess and constantly challenging herself by reentering school at Berklee, leads her band with vocals and on the piano. The Zahili Gonzalez Zamora Project, which features a drummer, an upright bassist, two horn players and a tenor saxophone, plays irresistible and sensual jazz fusion.
results.name: Harborwalk Sounds (Funk-Soul-Jazz) Presents: Zahili Gonzalez Zamora Project

results.description:
The wearable tech industry has really taken off in 2015. It seems as though the possibilities are endless. Tech in Motion Boston decided the best way to celebrate these possibilities would be to host a discussion on just where the future of this technology can take us! Join us at the Microsoft NERD Center on August 13th for a night with wearable tech experts, free refreshments, a cash bar, and as always, a lot of networking!

Meet our Panel of Experts:

William Crawford, VP of Engineering, Fitbit

William Crawford is a VP of Engineering and the head of the Boston office of Fitbit (NYSE:FIT), the leader in wearable technology and activity tracking. Before Fitbit he was the CEO of Linked Medical, a Boston-based spinoff from Massachusetts General Hospital. Prior to that Mr. Crawford ran Beacon 16, a design-and-build software consultancy serving the healthcare and research communities, and has held senior roles at Children’s Hospital Boston, PAREXEL and the US Department of Health and Human Services, all focused on connected technology. 

Keith Kocho, Co-Founder and CEO, Bloom

Keith brings more than 25 years of experience at the intersection of entertainment and technology to his current role as Co-founder and CEO of OrbitHCI, also known as Bloom. He previously founded ExtendMedia, which was acquired by Cisco in 2010 and has received such awards as the BDC's "Young Entrepreneur of the Year" and "Emerging Executive of the Year" by the Mass Technology Leadership Council. In addition, Keith has served as both advisor and board member to several private and public companies and has been granted several patents.


Mark Prince, VP of Consumer Business, Withings

Mark Prince is VP Consumer Business of Withings, the company that leads the connected health revolution.  Withings partners include Apple, Best Buy, and over 100 app partners. Prince previously held roles at PDP where he helped to launch the Disney Infinity program; Ambient Devices, a pioneer in connected consumer products; Numark (now InMusic Group), where he created and launched ION Audio; and at Continuum, a design and innovation consultancy. Prince's contributions include product innovation and design, brand development, and go to market strategy.

Maneesh Sethi, Founder, Pavlok


Maneesh Sethi is the founder of Pavlok --- the wearable device that uses electric shock to help you break bad habits. Plagued by attention and focus issues his entire life, Maneesh decided to invent a technology to help him regain control --- and break the bad habits that held him back. Maneesh and Pavlok have been featured on the Colbert Report, Late Night with Jimmy Fallon, Good Morning America and more. Maneesh also was the founder of Hack the System, where he showed the world how to write NYTimes Bestselling books, become a famous DJ in Berlin, start an NGO in India, travel first class for free, and more. Find out more at http://pavlok.com/

Jamie Tyler, Founder and CSO, Thync


Dr. Jamie Tyler is a Founder and the CSO of Thync. Jamie has deep experience in developing, applying, and advancing brain stimulation and non-invasive neuromodulation technologies. He has received several awards for his innovations in this area. Jamie serves as an expert on neuromodulation and human performance enhancement in many capacities. For more than two decades, Jamie has developed his expertise by studying brain circuit function, neurophysiology, and behavior at top-tier academic institutions. In addition to his role as CSO of Thync, Jamie concurrently holds a position as an Associate Professor in the School of Biological and Health Systems Engineering at Arizona State University.


Meet our Moderator: 

David Gerhardt, Marketing Manager at HubSpot

Dave Gerhardt is a marketing manager at HubSpot. Prior to HubSpot, he led Account Management & Client Services at Privy and spent three years as Product Marketing Manager at Constant Contact.  Dave is also the creator of Tech In Boston, a podcast and weekly newsletter that profiles the people and companies here in Boston.

As always a huge thank you to our monthly sponsors Jobspring Partners and Workbridge Associates. 


For live updates on the meetup follow us on Twitter @Tech_in_Motion, @JobspringBoston and @WorkbridgeMA. We look forward to meeting you at this fun-filled,  networking event. Feel free to bring a friend along! 

Interested in sponsoring Tech in Motion? Reach out to Courtney or Cara! 

Learn More About Our Advertising Sponsor:


The QS World MBA Tour will be making a stop in Boston on September 17th. Their event is your opportunity to meet with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools, and network with top tier MBA alumni who will share their study and career success stories. As an attendee, you will be eligible to apply for exclusive MBA scholarships worth $1.7M and attend panels and seminars to have all of your MBA questions answered in one place. Entry is free for members of Tech in Motion Boston, but places are limited so make sure you register today.
results.name: The Future of Wearables: A Panel Discussion

results.description:
Take The  8 Steps That Will Change Your Life

The Original Steppers of Boston has earned two  Steppin' Instruction Certifications**.                            


Every Thursday

Classes - Practice - Open Dance

Beginners Welcome!!
Men, Women, Singles, Couples

 

Instructional Hours:

 

Beginners Class 6pm -7pm

Everyone Else Class 7pm-8pm


Open Dance & Practice 8pm - Until


 

The Original Steppers of Boston offer Certified Chicago Style Steppin' dance instruction for the new beginner to the seasoned stepper. We also host a supportive environment for steppers to practice and participate in an open dance to hone their dance skills.

We welcome you to stop by to get an idea of what Steppin' Chicago Style is all about. There is a $10 participation fee to get on the dance floor, first visit is FREE. A partner is encouraged, but not required.

Doors open at 6:00pm.

*** Please wear comfortable clothes and smooth bottom shoes (NO SNEAKERS, MARKING SOLES or RUBBER BOTTOMS)!  Gentlemen must remove their hats. Powder is not allowed on the dance floor***

Bring your Steppin' notebook
Courtesy Note:: Please be on time.
Practice outside of class is expected and necessary.

Class attendance may be a prerequisite for the Royce Banks Steppin' Is A Lifestyle Workshops.

**Certified Instruction provided by The Original Steppers of Boston Inc 2006 Team**

Full Bar!!  Free Parking!! Kitchen is Open!!

We ask that you patronize the bar and tip the staff for their services.

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lzQYE4HRygM
results.name: "Chicago Style" Steppin' Dance Class & Practice for All Levels

results.description:
Everyday objects are becoming smarter. They can sense what goes on in the environment, collect information about us, and tailor our interactions and experiences in innovative ways.

And now these things are starting to connect with one another, creating new ecosystems of products and services that require a novel approach to how we imagine, design, and make.


THE MEME invites you to an evening of conversation where we will be Reimagining Connected Objects. Join experienced leaders in the field as they discuss how they are researching, developing, and making the next generation of connected object experiences.

This is our second IoT event this year (the first on Meetup!), so keep an eye out for updates. We have three speakers confirmed for the panel: David Rose (CEO at Ditto Labs, Author of Enchanted Objects, Lecturer & Researcher at MIT Media Lab), Joseph Biron (VP of IoT Technology at ThingWorx), and Dipul Patel (Co-Founder & CEO of ecoVent).
results.how_to_find_us: Workbar Cambridge is less than a block away from the MBTA Red Line (Central stop).  It is also just a short walk from the 1, CT1, 91, and 47 bus routes.
results.name: Reimagining Connected Objects

FREE Summer Yoga returns to The Boston Common Frog Pond!

A vibrant group of instructors leads power vinyasa flow for over 100 students of all levels. This style of yoga provides a space for all to challenge themselves, release stress, expand energy, and tap into the beauty of trees, grass, and water found at Boston’s most historic park.

Classes run June 4th – August 27th.

Meet us on the Common Parade Ground, behind the Carousel, every Thursday 6:00pm-7:15pm.

More info: http://bostonfrogpond.com/warm-weather-programs/free-summer-yoga/

results.description:
Come dragon boat with Living Root! We're a co-ed team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. This is a great way to get in shape, meet people, and do something fun and competitive.  We meet at 6pm at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station.  We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather.  Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you dont mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings.  We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice, and you're welcome to join us.  Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked]. 

Additional Location and Parking information can be found here

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP Now in its tenth year, the weekly Boston Poetry (formerly “Charles River Writers”) has long been a free forum for literary fellowship and discussion. It is entirely free and open to the public.

To participate, please RSVP here, and arrive bearing enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss – whether prose or verse – for each participant to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies of your writing, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! Likewise let us know if you’d like to suggest a writing exercise or event.

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

The ICA free Harborwalk Sounds summer concert series are back again!  With stand-out talent from Boston’s Berklee School of Music set against gorgeous harbor views, the free outdoor concert series is a perfect way to spend a summer evening. Grab a snack from our delicious summer menu and hit the galleries for free to make an entire evening of it.

http://www.icaboston.org/programs/ICA_Summer/

Admission to the museum is also free!

The concert takes place in the rear of the building, the back entrance to the museum.  There are a series of steps and a wide-space area where the musicians set-up their stage.  These steps face the water and have a gorgeous view of the Boston harbor. 

For meeting purposes, lets meet at the bottom (front-row), center  of the steps at 6:30pm. 

Remember, follow the WATER and to go to FRONT ROW, CENTER.  I will try to hold a Meetup sign to help you find the group.

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and intend to meet members of the group. If you reserve "YES", we will be expecting you.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group. 

I look forward in enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

******************************************

Directions and Public Transportation

If you are traveling via public transportation, the nearest T stop is the Waterfront on the Silver Line, http://www.icaboston.org/visit/directions-and-parking/public-transport/

For driving directions, please refer to <a>http://www.icaboston.org/visit/directions-and-parking//</a>;

******************************************

Concert Details

******************************************

Concert Details


Zahili Gonzalez Zamora Project

Funk, soul, jazz improvisation, and the traditions of Cuban music are the sparkplugs that drive the Zahili Gonzaleez Zamora Project. Zahili Gonzalez Zamora, trained at Havana’s National Conservatory of Music, was playing classical music ten hours a day by age 14 and it was only after touring as a professional musician that she discovered her love for improvisation and jazz. Now the talented arranger and composer, expanding her musical prowess and constantly challenging herself by reentering school at Berklee, leads her band with vocals and on the piano. The Zahili Gonzalez Zamora Project, which features a drummer, an upright bassist, two horn players and a tenor saxophone, plays irresistible and sensual jazz fusion.

http://www.icaboston.org/programs/performance/music/harborwalk-sounds2015/zahili_gonzalez_zamora_project/
results.name: ICA - Harborwalk Sounds Concert! Zahili Gonzalez Zamora Project - Free!

results.description:
Refactoring in Ember by Dave Wasmer

The Ember landscape is full of change over the past few months as we approach 2.0 stable and beyond. This talk will explore techniques we use at Kinvey for refactoring  old Ember code to stay ahead of the curve and maintain a clean, up-to-date codebase.


Observing Ember Addons by Katie Gengler 

The Ember addon ecosystem is growing rapidly, with over a thousand addons so far and more being created every day. Let’s take a look at some of the most popular addons, and some of the categories that don’t have a clear winner.

Lightning Talks:

Lauren Tan on ember-metrics
Robert Jackson with an Ember 2.0 update
results.name: Refactoring in Ember and Observing Ember Addons

results.description:
Please join us for a childcare panel for single parents

There are many childcare options, but what is the right choice for your family? Join Care Academy, Cultural Care Au Pair and Pine Village for a panel discussion featuring local experts in the field sharing information to help you make an informed decision when it comes to childcare for your little ones.

This event is brought to you in conjunction with Deanna Coyle, Financial Consultant. She has spent years establishing a network of caring divorce professionals who provide resources to the community for those going through divorce. Having been through divorce herself with two young children, she understands the challenges and life changes that occur during this journey. She is dedicated to empowering individuals to feel educated through their divorce and revolutionize the divorce process. This event will be focused on single parents and their need for various types of childcare services.

Admission is free. The event will feature a panel discussion, Q&A session, and light refreshments.

results.description:
We'll be teaming up with CocoaHeads Boston again this month!


Speakers:

Sara Robinson, Developer Advocate at Firebase


"Building Awesome Swift Apps with Firebase"

Firebase can function as the complete backend for your iOS app, and makes building realtime, collaborative mobile apps easy. Our iOS SDK allows for easy data storage and syncing, locally caches data so that your app continues to work in spotty internet connections, and handles use authentication without the need for custom server code. During this talk, Sara will explain how you can use the Firebase iOS SDK with Swift to build awesome apps without running a server. She’ll end the talk with some live coding.

Join us for an evening of radiant bliss...enter that space inside you that is already awakened...feel and become openness and peace, and love itself.
Then, pass on the peace to Mother Earth.

We are all in our awakening process...becoming awake to the Presence within us and living, speaking, loving and creating from that place. To access and maintain that truth of who we really are requires us to let go of any limiting beliefs, habits, memories. Then we can more fully embrace and embody the higher consciousness of our true Self.   
       No matter where you are on your path of awakening, you will love this sacred way of being in divine energy with like-minded people! Whatever you want next in life, this program will help you achieve it with ease and grace. The Divine Presence becomes apparent as unconditional love and joy.

Judy guides this class based on her ongoing deep studies in the area of conscious awakening.  At these meetings we can freely express and connect with like-hearted souls as we share in these powerful energy transmissions. All are welcome to join us and share your own challenges, experiences, intentions and joys. If being in sacred energy appeals to you, you will love this gathering. At the end of our time together we will join our energies in a circle to pass on healing and higher frequencies to Mother Earth and all creatures.

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay

results.description:
The MFA is doing a series of Ingrid Bergman films and Gaslight is one I've never seen.

From the MFA website:

Gaslight by George Cukor (1944, 114 min.). Years after her aunt was murdered in her home, Paula (Ingrid Bergman) moves back into the house with her new husband, Gregory (Charles Boyer). He has a secret, however, that he will do anything to protect, and he convinces Paula that she is sick and unable to go outside. Isolated in the house, Paula starts to hear strange noises and see odd things. Is she really going insane or is her husband making her mad? Bergman’s tortured performance earned her an Academy Award for Best Actress, her first of three.

Does your mind go all fuzzy when you think about focusing?  This month's workshop meeting will be devoted to focusing and depth of field.  We'll work with Thelma the mannequin in the studio to understand how to control depth of field, how and where to focus, and the range of artistic effects that can be achieved with different choices about focusing and depth of field. 


In this controlled environment (Thelma is very patient!) you will be able to try different techniques using your own camera and compare the results that you get.  You will be able to learn from your fellow club members and also help them out.


Frank Simard will lead the workshop.  Please bring your cameras and your focusing questions!

Hey Everyone, 

Tired of watching the local sports games on the couch alone?

Join us at one of the coolest Irish Pubs on the North Shore, and play in a weekly free cornhole tournament, where the winning teams get gift certificates to the Pub/Restaurant. 

Both men and women love playing, and if you don't have a partner, we'll match you up with someone. Many times, we have a random draw for partners. There have been a few couples made from coming to our events. 

The food, beer, and appetizers are great....and they have multiple large TVs to watch the Bruins game while we play.

John Barera could be considered our Tamo Sumo (Panorama Bar). Having pioneered his sound at various parties, John joined us recently and has never quite looked back. His career recently brought him to a party of a few thousand in London.


Coralcola? Let's call him Erol Alkan (Trash, London). Like Erol, Coralcola can dive into electro or indie (or emo!) just as easily as he can crush a killer techno set.

A resident DJ has a special place in our heart, and these three are no different. As per usual, a resident DJ night is free before 11pm so get there early and dive in... the water's just fine.

results.description:
In celebration of Boston's Coworking Week we will be holding an all day Open House for those who would like to pop in and spend the day! We will then be holding our w-Rap Mixer listening to the sounds of classic rap beats with drinks and snacks to end the week. What better way to end the work week on a Friday?! So come join us in celebration. You can find a list of all the  events and activities at the other local Boston coworking spaces here http://goo.gl/50YMv9. Be sure to check them out! :)

About Coalition: Coalition is a top coworking space in Downtown Crossing (hyper-centrally located atop the red, orange, and green lines!). All of our members are revenue-generating and over half are veteran entrepreneurs with multiple businesses. Our spaces and events are built to make it easier for entrepreneurs to bounce ideas off each other. Community is very important to us, as we work to connect our members to the startup ecosystem, investors, and others who can help you grow. 

About Coworking Week: In 2005 an independent worker in California conceived of a different way of working; he envisioned a place where independent workers could come together, collaborate and reap the rewards of community, increased productivity and creativity. That worker was Brad Neuberg and the word he used to describe his vision was coworking, and he was a founder of Coworking (a one day a week reserved space in another community center in 2005) and a co-founder of The Hat Factory. On August 9th, approximately 500 coworking spaces around the world will celebrate Neuberg’s vision as part of International Coworking Day. Boston will be celebrating the week of August 10th-14th
results.name: Coalition's All Day Open House and Coworking Week End wRap-up Mixer!

For New Members AND NON-Members:

For every sailor who walks through our door, start here! This FREE Orientation class will get you familiar with how everything works at CBI. The orientation class is the gateway to everything that CBI has to offer, whether you’re a seasoned sailor or brand new to boats. Done entirely on the dock, your orientation will include a guided tour of CBI’s boats and facilities, an overview of our classes and programs, as well as plenty of time to ask the questions that matter to you as a sailor. All orientations meet at the base of the American Flag Pole out on the dock, and runs for about half an hour. All are welcome to this class!


Afterwards, we invite you to meet one another and ask about other Orientation class attendees' prior experience with sailing. Perhaps you can find a friend to take the Beginner Sailing classes together with once you join. 

Friday Nights are also when CBI members go out for Informal Racing, so it is an exciting night to watch the sailors and learn more about how you can progress your skills after learning to sail. Certainly ask your Orientation instructor about the Friday Night Informal Racing and Informal Instruction if he or she does not mention it. If you have any questions, please feel free to post below!

results.description:
This social activity is completely voluntary, and not-for-profit: no compensation of any kind is required or expected for participation. By boarding my boat, you explicitly agree to assume full personal responsibility for your own safety and well-being, and indemnify me against any legal liability

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sailing Info 

Please read disclaimer at the bottom of the page before you RSVP

Who can come
Everybody is invited.
I will be skippering the boat in and out of the mooring field and will be taking over when needed. Once we are in clear waters we will be taking turns at the tiller.


Where
We will be sailing in the Boston inner harbor, and might venture out and sail around one of the Boston Harbor Islands.


What 

- we will sail on
Boston 27 (Based on Soling) , Sonar, or Soling. You can learn more about these boats here: http://www.bostonharborsailing.com/fleet_boston27.html


- to expect
A laid back and safe sailing adventure to the extent it is possible on the racing boat without the engine or bathroom in the busy harbor.

In perfect conditions Boston 27 is a comfortable boat to sail on, but in the strong winds boat will lean and you might get splashed. On a windy day be prepared to pull on the ropes, move around, get splashed, and not have much down-time.

Be warned that it can get stressful at times and we will need to react quickly. . Remember, these boats don’t have engines and we will have to rely on the wind power. During stressful situations it is important to stay calm and to work as a team.

- will be on the boat
Two flotation pillows and four life jackets.


- is important
Safety will be our number one priority. I will give a safety crash course once we are on the boat. I recommend that everyone wears a life jacket.


- to bring
Sunscreen, hat, sunglasses, water, and a cell phone. Sailing Boston 27 or Soling on a windy day can get you splashed. I would recommend bringing a change of clothes and getting a waterproof case for you cell phone or wrapping it in a plastic bag.


- I will bring
My own gear, two-way UHF floating radio pre-programmed with the sailing club and Coast Guard channels and a winch handle to help tighten the sails.


Disclaimer
Sailing can be and will be stressful at times.
It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is part of the sport.

results.description:
This group will meet monthly to look at popular films through the lens of spirituality/faith.  All are welcome to join the screening of a recent film followed by a discussion led by a local theologian.

Friday, August 14, 6:30 pm

Faith and Film (BYOB)

“Life Itself: The Only Thing Roger Loved More Than Movies”

Based on his bestselling memoir of the same name, Life Itself, explores the impact and legacy of Roger Ebert’s life, from his Pulitzer Prize-winning film criticism at the Chicago Sun-Times to becoming one of the most influential  cultural voices in America..

Despite his "leave of presence," his body of work stands as a great populist monument, accessible inspiration for the next generations of film lovers. Life Itself gives a definitive document of the flesh and blood man who forever changed what it meant to be at the movies: Roger Ebert. 

““a story that is by turns personal, wistful, funny, painful, and transcendent”

“America's most gladiatorial film critic (those thumbs!) is celebrated with bawdy humor and unabashed heart in Steve James' documentary Life Itself.

Screening and Discussion led by Rev. Anastasia Kidd and Rev. Chad Kidd; A Free Will Offering will be collected.

6:30 pm doors open

6:45 Screening

8:45 - 9:30 Discussion

We will provide High Definition films on large screen, comfortable seating, light snacks and a great discussion leader!  A free will offering will be collected at the time of the film.  BYOBeer, Wine and Soda.

Call <a>[masked]</a> or email <a>[masked]</a> to find out the film title and to get on our mailing list for details about our monthly Faith and Film events as well as our other Arts and Inspiration programs (music, art gallery, and the spoken word).


Also: see the events page at sanctuaryucc.org

These are 2 separate businesses, a meal at the restaurant is around $10-$15, 

Swing Dance Lesson at the studio (included w/ price of admission): 8:00pm – 9:00pm.  

YOU SHOULD PLAN TO ATTEND THE LESSON IF YOU NEVER DANCED BEFORE, OTHERWISE YOU WILL NOT ENJOY THE DANCE.  Which means you should order the food AS SOON as you arrive.

LIVE MUSIC: Dan Fox Foxtet with Amy Kucharik

The Foxtet is a six piece band led by trombonist Dan Fox and comprised of some of the best local musicians who have decades of combined experience playing for swing dancers. The Foxtet also features the lovely Amy Kucharik on vocals and ukulele. Fox has worked as a sideman at Boston Swing Central with Adrian Cunningham, The Lowdown Stompers, the Easy Winners and with Shawn Hershey. Expect a rock-solid beat and sweet, swinging horns playing tunes from the ’20’s and ’30’s at just the right tempos.

Joining Dan on vocals for this evening is Amy Kucharik, a singer-songwriter based in Somerville, MA known for sweet ukulele sounds and sassy lyrics, delivered with a voice and style that recall early jazz and blues performers. Amy has performed at swing dance venues in Somerville, Cambridge, and the greater Boston area as well as Philadelphia, Baltimore, Dallas and St. Louis.


Dancing: 9:00pm – 12:00am 
General Admission: $15 
Students and Seniors (with Valid ID): $13

I can pickup people at the red line, Alewife Station, if needed. I am also asking for help if other people can do the same.  The place is just 0.8 mile from the station.  Which will take you around 17 minutes to walk.

See map here

Feel free to come just for the dinner or the dance.

---PARKING

lots of parking onsite. In addition to the Extreme Dancesport lot, you can park in any of the additional parking lots across the street and within nearby businesses (like the local gym). This information is also available on the Extreme Dancesport website! http://www.extremedancesport.com/about_us/hours_directions/index.html

results.description:
Ghost Town Blues Band:
Beale Street’s latest success story and 2014 INTERNATIONAL BLUES CHALLENGE 2nd Place Winner is Ghost Town Blues Band. Not your grandpa’s blues band, their live show has been captivating audiences in the U.S. and Canada with a second-line horn entrance, cigar box guitars and electric push brooms to Allman Brothers style jams and their rapping trombone player. Both Preston McEwen behind the drums and Matt Karner on the bass guitar are a punishing rhythm section behind frontman Matt Isbell with raunchy cigar box guitar licks and chainsaw rhythms. With the addition of Trombonist Suavo Jones, Jeremy Powell on keys and finally Josh Roberts on lead guitar, the grooves go from funky to funk-nasty as the band gains more notoriety in the blues and jam circuit.

Ghost Town Blues Band is a modern blues band with an intimate knowledge of both blues, rock and improvisational jams. At the same time, the band’s raw energy and intensity is reminiscent of some of the best blues that rock n' roll has ever offered. The band can turn on a dime from North Mississippi hill country grooves to classic electric urban blues and funk and Allman Brothers style jams. This Memphis-based, gritty, seven-piece has been touring the US and Canada since its inception in 2009, gaining a strong following within the Blues and Jam Band circuit.

“GTBB shows what can happen when the past is distilled through young sensibilities, voices, and instruments. This is 21st century blues at its best.” - Living Blues Magazine 2011

Ticket price in advance: $8.00 until 4 pm[masked] if tickets are still available. 

At door: $10 

In order to reserve a table for dinner, I have to have six people signed up with a firm commitment.

http://johnnyds.tunestub.com/event.cfm?id=207427&cart

Doors open at 5:30 pm Show begins at 7:30 pm
Show Type: Funk
Advanced Tickets are available until 4 pm,[masked]
(if not Sold Out prior)

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Learn about the history iconic Roland products (like the TR-808, TR-909, TB-303, SH-101, PROMARS etc) and how in the hands of artists, they played a role in shaping today’s music genres. This event is designed for musicians and music aficionados to be able to learn about both the history and technology of electronic music production and performance. With roots in the very origins of electronic music, AIRA is a new series of products designed to meet the evolving needs of today's electronic musicians. In the studio or on the stage, AIRA brings genre-defining sounds and modern performance features to a new generation. While computers dominate so many music production activities today, artists still seek inspiration through the sonic character and responsive feel of traditional analog hardware. AIRA products emphasize the spontaneous creativity and hands-on performance inspired by these vintage electronic instruments, while integrating neatly into today’s computer-based production environments.
results.name: AIRA House (8/14) #FREE

results.description:
Hello everyone, I hope everyone is enjoying Summer!

I just wanted to touch base regarding our forthcoming Death Cafe. Time is 7 pm to 9 pm. 

As always, I will provide cakes and tea. This time, there will be just two types of tea - a hot tea and an iced tea.  In the interest of getting into the subject and not to miss anything, it would be easier to just have simpler fare.

Just for information, I live on the second floor, and there is no elevator.  Street Parking is available.  Also public transportation, #39 MTBA, Green Line, E. Heath Stop.

Once again, I suggest that everyone reads about Death Cafe (Deathcafe.com), so we are all on the same page.

We do not suggest anything, nor do we recommend anything, we are a group of people who are gathered to share and talk about Death/Life. Simply.  We are very respectful of each other and we try to make sure everyone gets a chance to speak.

I am excited and so looking forward and I hope you are too!

With gratitude, Carolyn
results.name: At a Death Cafe we gather to eat cake, drink tea and discuss death, hence, life.
