results.description:
♫♫ In the jungle, the mighty jungle, Bike Party rules the night ♫♫

Release your inner party animal and take a ride on the wild side!

We’ll swing, slither, and swoop through the streets with our paws on our handlebars, howling with joy toward all we pass. Unleash your beastly moves at party stops where our animal kingdom will rage together under the new moon!

This month, Boston is our jungle, and Bike Party has Gone Wild!

** This is a casual paced, night time, social, bike ride with a few hundred participants.  Typically we have 2 or 3 party stops to regroup, hang out, dance, make friends, & have fun.

** Check out the Facebook Event Page to invite your friends and to get updates on the Route and other fun things.


** If you've never been to a Boston Bike Party ride, this video shows what it's all about.

** Check out the LOOKBOOK for ideas on how to dress (optional, but fun!)
results.name: Boston Bike Party: Gone Wild!

results.description:
The vineyards surrounding Verona in northeast Italy produce a lovely palette of gentle wines, from simple to profound.  Let's get together and explore the soft and versatile whites, the equally agreeable reds and perhaps even some rosé.  We will of course focus on Valplolicella in styles ranging from light trattoria wine to the richer more complex Ripasso, and we want to end with a flight of Amarone della Valpolicella, the "vino da meditazione" which is the legendary way to conclude any Veronese feast.  Amarone is one of Italy's most distinctive wines, being made from late-harvested grapes that are then partially dried for months to concentrate their sugars, resulting in wine that is highly concentrated, velvety, and potent. 


When you RSVP, please indicate whether you prefer to bring one of the following wines:  Soave, Lugana, Valpolicella, Bardolino, Chiaretto, Ripasso  OR contribute $20 toward a flight of Amarone.  We only need 1-2 people to contribute money, so we'll have to work that out.


Please bring 4 glasses, a bottle of wine OR a $20 contribution, and $10 toward food.
results.name: Valpolicella - The Gentlemen of Verona

results.description:
WBZ NewsRadio 1030 and the Department of Conservation and Recreation host the 30th Annual Free Fridays flicks movie series at the DCR Hatch Shell. Free Friday flicks start at dusk (8:15+ as the summer goes along) but activities and fun kick off at 6 p.m. on Fridays this summer!

Free Friday Flicks is a summertime tradition in Boston, attracting thousands of movie-goers to enjoy family-oriented feature length movies under the stars all summer long at DCR’s Hatch Shell in Boston! Bring a blanket or lawn chair, pack a picnic, and watch a movie with family and friends on Friday night for free! Movies begin at sundown, but arrive early to grab your spot on the lawn and enjoy free food samples, games, and giveaways with WBZ NewsRadio 1030 – the fun.
results.name: Free Friday Flicks-Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good Very Bad Day

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the building.  The stairs will bring you to the door.
results.name: (Newton) Intermediate Longsword, Dagger and Grappling

results.description:
KaaKaaaw!  KaaKaaaw!You hear that?  That's right, its the call of the wild inviting you and your pack, flock, gaggle, or herd, of friends to join a few hundred bike riding beasts as we get all Hakuna Matata together.  So mark your calendars, (we assume you animals keep meticulously organized calendars) because the next Boston Bike Party rolls out of Copley Square at 8pm on August 14th!
♫♫ In the jungle, the mighty jungle, Bike Party rules the night ♫♫

Release your inner party animal and take a ride on the wild side!

We’ll swing, slither, and swoop through the streets with our paws on our handlebars, howling with joy toward all we pass. Unleash your beastly moves at party stops where our animal kingdom will rage together under the new moon!

This month, Boston is our jungle, and Bike Party has Gone Wild!
http://bostonbikeparty.com/category/rides/


https://ci4.googleusercontent.com/proxy/qD0qGlv_U9NC5LzTT66As537msVpO7NWDGnH_mCK88Bqi4lTQ7RFZ4ljsYgfGsz34i38XapED0k2Y16tO3cItzN5RdeZXSxaTbVyLOHMZLU8vIKDRMMeEAjWn0LOU8isHnmO_R0Rm8RwC-gW4fYVLD3yTgLYVPe9aaBM9wMC2v9fujLL8bsyhCkSxW1SAInMi6D4cUOlKFCCT5mEHTrXpgZZfQWu4FKMA5nb8zD4O_soGDpk=s0-d-e1-ft#https://scontent-lga1-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xpf1/v/t1.0-9/11846733_487418488083114_6546469124572104259_n.jpg?oh=1c4abecfd8cc189d0d46e9e8bfb57139&oe=564A463B

This is a fun event - not a fast ride, more like meandering through the streets of Boston. You'll get to see parts you wouldn't normally visit. Two guys pull trailers with speakers playing music. Two 15 min. stops along the way to sway and dance.  Always a party-theme, so get ready to get your costumes. 

Expect the ride part to end around 10:30 and then you have to get back to your car... unless you park at the end and bike to Copley Sq. Expect folks to go out for food and drinks afterwards, so if you're a night owl, this'll suit you fine. I just ride and go home to my pillow ; > 

If you're in after 5 pm and out by 8 am, you can get $10 parking at Central Parking, 100 Clarendon St Boston MA 02116 (617)[masked], which is right by Copley Sq and the Mass Pike and not far from I-93. 


Do not expect to be able to take the commuter rail home. The ride ends too late to rely on that.

results.description:
Our meetup starts at Deer Island water treatment plant. This is a public walkway that many people use to jog at night, it is safe, but a bit of a walk - about a 2.6 mile loop. Hiking boots recommended, as always, especially if you want to climb the hill south of the water tanks.


We'll meet just after sunset and there will be no moon - it's a new moon night.  So if it's clear, it will be a good night for star trails, and perhaps a Milky Way attempt. There is plenty to shoot if you stick to the jogging path.  If you stray from the path or take the paths up the hill on the north side of the plant, you will want to have a flashlight handy, but please be considerate of others if you need to light your way.

Below are some images to give you an idea. Bring your lens shades to avoid flares, anything from super-wide to medium zoom will be usable. Shooting the water tanks from the hill can even use some 200 mm zooming.

Deer island is actually quite dark and we may be able to catch the Milky Way shooting south-east, which is the best part, anyway. 


It may be somewhat smelly in some of the places, this is a water / sewage treatment plan, but it's not too bad.

There are many great and very different objects to shoot in this location, from a wind mill, rusty anchor points, water tanks, stairs, a grassy hill to the rotten poles sticking out the water. And the area is large, the group can spread out without getting into each other's way.

More pictures:

http://www.meetup.com/GBNight/photos/17649482/
results.name: Deer Island Star trails

results.description:
Please note the change of time. We are starting earlier in the morning to finish the run before it gets hot :-). 

Planned mileage: 9 for half-marathoners and 16.41 for full marathoners. 

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course.

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM. 

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances.

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. Alternatively, It's a short distance from Concord High School. Some people avoid the parking fee by parking near Concord High School and then walk/ride their bike over to Walden. Click here for the map of the parking.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile mile; a perfect distance for those training for 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

This meetup is important because you always want to swim in groups if you can. Make certain that you look out for each other. Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.

For those that are really new and nervous about open water swimming, stay tuned for a beginners clinic that I'll put on in the summer.

results.name: Weekly Walden Open Water Swim

results.description:
The Charles River, originally named Massachusetts River, was founded by explorer Captain John Smith who mapped the coast of New England.
Dedham’s portion of the Charles offers smooth water with a moderate current. The Water Trail is located entirely in Dedham and is made a loop by Long Ditch, located in Cutler Park. The Water Trail follows the lead of organized hiking trails, by marking the trail with mile markers and signs at launches and at significant historical and ecological locations. The goal of the Water Trail is to attract visitors to the Charles and create an educational and lasting experience that would in turn create environmental stewards of the river. There are currently 5 public launch sites along the Water Trail of which several are adjacent to the many acres of Dedham’s parks and conservation lands. Some of the things paddlers will encounter, besides the unique flora and fauna that the River supports, are: the landing place of Contentment's (Dedham's) first settlers in 1635; the place of the first cart path over the Charles River; Cutler Park, the largest marsh area on the Charles River; the Castle "Riverdale" at the Noble and Greenough School built for railroad tycoon Albert Nickerson in 1890; 

Mother Brook, believed to be the first man made canal in the United States and the course for the first water driven, broad powered loom in the world; Powder House, built in 1766 stored military supplies through the period of the American Revolution; as well as several other sites .

here is the link to the water loop trail.  We are meeting at number 1 the Dolan Center: http://www.dedhamtrails.com/map.html

RENTALS:

Through the generosity of L.L. Bean the Town now has 4 kayaks and 2 canoes that it rents out on weekends. Please contact the Town of Dedham Recreation Department to reserve a rental at[masked]-9250.  Hurry they book fast!
results.name: KAYAK THE DEDHAM WATER LOOP

results.description:
Would you like to improve your relationships,
with yourself & with others?
Are you looking to know yourself more?

Do you desire more honesty, trust, peace and balance in your relationships?

Are you searching for greater self confidence in creating relationships? 

Dianne Sleek’s Intimacy Workshop is returning to Boston on August 15 & 16, 2015!

This two day workshop will be a powerful step in the journey to face ourselves honestly & compassionately, to expose the layers underneath and find more intimacy in our lives.

Some of the topics we’ll delve into are with significant relationships in our lives:

lovers, spouses, friends, colleagues, money, creative expression, our work, Spirit, self attitude and care, our body, our inner child, and the ability to work Forgiveness.

Dianne Sleek has spent 40 years exploring the fascinating world of self awareness. For 16 years she was a facilitator, both in the US and internationally for INSIGHT SEMINARS.  She brings years of experience, a loving heart, understanding, trust & a powerful sense of compassion to her work.

Experience a rare weekend discovering how great it feels to powerfully acknowledge ourselves and to explore and grow into our best selves.

Is this for you?  The intimacy workshop is....

·  for those looking to improve strained relationships

·  for those looking for greater honesty and trust in their relationships

·  for those searching for more peace and balance in their relationships

·  for those seeking greater self confidence in creating intimate relationships

·  for those desiring to understand and adapt in their relationships; to create greater harmony

·  for those looking to know and enjoy themselves more

(Requirements: Prior Human Growth work is a prerequisite for the Intimacy weekend)

TUITION:  $300.00 PER PERSON OR $450.00 PER COUPLE

REGISTER NOW!  This seminar will fill up quickly.

LOCATION: Four Points by Sheraton Wakefield Boston Hotel & Conference Center,  1 Audubon Road, Wakefield, Massachusetts.

For more information or to register, contact SUE CHILTON at [masked] or[masked] (in Canada; check your phone plan!) 

Intimacy between people requires closeness as well as distance.  It is like dancing.  Sometimes we are very close, touching, holding each other, sometimes we move away and let the space between us become the area where we can freely move.  To keep the right balance between closeness and distance requires work – since the needs of the partners may be quite different at any given moment.  A perfect balance seldom occurs, but the search for the balance can give birth to a beautiful dance.

  Henri J.M. Nouwen  BREAD for the JOURNEY

More About the Presenter:

Ms. Sleek has also worked inside corporate America consulting in executive coaching, team building projects, as well as collaborative problem solving and conflict resolution. Going back to her earlier roots Dianne now heads up a highly successful performing arts school as Director of Theater. Dianne is instrumental in developing the careers and hearts of many artists entering a highly competitive field. Throughout the years wherever her journey has taken her Dianne holds the possibilities of the Human Spirit in the highest regard. Working to achieve all that we can be and experience in this lifetime.


What does Dianne have to say about Intimacy and the workshop? –

What is INTIMACY?  Is it any one thing?  Intimacy is sometimes defined as a passionate connection, a feeling of being close and belonging.  What are the places in your world, your life that hold those passionate connections?  Places where you create intimacy, commune with intimacy, breathe intimacy.

Genuine Intimacy requires dialogue, transparency, vulnerability, courage and truthful exchange.  It is a process of building trust in our relationships (human and otherwise).  It is what enables us to disclose, in confidence, previously hidden thoughts and feelings that then bind us together. 

What is it that we do to block this state…..why do we fear it yet yearn, long for it?  Intimacy touches us physically, emotionally, intellectually and spiritually.  It is sometimes said that our individual worlds and the way we view them, the way we live in our world is in many ways a culmination of what we each have created for ourselves.  My life, your life is sometimes outside of our control, more often though, even more than we want to accept or dare to acknowledge it is our creation.  There are people who find comfort in the familiar, even if it is not what they truly want and choose to accept life happens.  Others quest, search for pathways not always conscious – not always comfortable, to know a bigger truth, to be peaceful in themselves and be alive. 

This two day workshop will be another step in that journey to face ourselves honestly and compassionately, to expose the layers underneath and find more Intimacy in our lives.  If We Dare!

results.name: Dianne Sleek: Intimacy Workshop

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

President opens meeting and welcomes guests

Toastmaster's Welcome 

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches

Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction

Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations

Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks 

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org


<a href="http://watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org/"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left.
results.name: Watertown Saturday Toastmasters Club Meeting

results.description:
I was planning to do a repeat of the 41-mile double loop ride that I came up with last year and has been done a few times since in this group. However, it looks like I won't have time for the 2nd loop, so I'm offering a slightly extended version of the first loop. Maybe somebody else wants to lead the second loop?

The extension is that rather than catching up with the Bruce Freeman Rail Trail in Kate's Corner, we head further north and catch up with it in Chelmsford Center. That adds about four miles, for 27 miles total.


Here's the new route and cue-sheet, including the 4 extra miles:

http://ridewithgps.com/routes/9827582

When: 
Let's meet up at 9:15 am and be ready to start at 9:30 am. Aiming to be back before 12:30 pm.

Where: 
The public parking lot on Keyes Rd, right in the center of Concord (it has public restrooms and a water fountain).

Who: 
You need to be okay with a 12-15 mph pace. We will wait for everyone at the top of major hills and at confusing intersections, but please don't sign up if you can't keep at least a 12 mph average pace with relatively few stops.

What's required: 
* Road bike in good repair 
* Bike helmet 
* At least one full large water bottle (you can refill at lunch) 
* Spare tube, and air

What's recommended: 
* Basic repair tools 
* Snack 
* Cell phone

A few lunch options:

• If you bring your own, then the picnic tables by the brook right off the parking lot are ideal. 

• Main Streets Market & Cafe has a small take-out shop right next to these picnic tables that serves "Burritos, Pizzas, Hotdogs, Sandwiches, Smoothies & Ice Cream". They sometimes get too crowded and run out of stuff. Also, I walked by them today and noticed that it now says cash only.

• Their main restaurant is in the same building, with an entrance on Main St. It would take too long to eat there, but they are great if you are looking for ice coffee or homemade lemonade to go. 

• Helen's Restaurant is across the street, at 17 Main St. Standard coffee and sandwiches, cash only.

• Haute Coffee is in an alley on the right, 100' down Walden St. Fancy coffee and sandwiches.
results.name: Concord-Chelmsford 27-mile loop

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.

results.description:
This free orientation and tour introduces you to the resources available at the NEHGS research facility. Founded in 1845, NEHGS is the country's oldest and largest nonprofit genealogy library and archive. With more than 15 million artifacts, books, manuscripts, microfilms, journals, photographs, and records--and expert staff to help you navigate it all-- NEHGS provides the access you need to research your family history. You do not have to be a member to participate. Tour attendees are welcome to use our resources following the tour. No registration necessary.

I'll be staying to use the resources for the first time!  Looking forward to it!.  And maybe lunch in the neighborhood?
results.name: New Visitor Tour New England Historic Genealogical Society

results.description:
•Ever wanted to improve your composition skills? •Are you baffled by the rule of thirds? •Want to learn about framing your shot and object placement? •Want to make your shots more dynamic? Then join this small group, limited to 10 for a relaxed walkabout and photo shoot focusing solely on composition. You can even leave your camera on automatic for this one. Workshop is suitable for all levels and camera types including point and shoots. Fee just $45 includes written handout covering the essentails of composition. We will shoot at various sites around the City of Boston from 10am m to 3pm approx. under the expert guidance of professional photographer,Ian Murray. <a>http://www.ianmurrayp...</a>;.

Book early to ensure a place.

Here is what previous participants on this workshop had to say:

“ The workshop organization was great: three exercises in three locations, each one clearly spelled out in detail. I enjoyed Ian's laid-back manner of instruction that was as encouraging as it was informative. I was hoping for a workshop that would get me to see things beyond the way I usually see and think about them through the lens, and that is exactly what I got. I would recommend this workshop for anyone who is trying to get a good overview of what composition is all about, and for anyone who wants to challenge themselves to get outside of their compositional comfort zone. ” "I really enjoyed the workshop a lot and learned a lot. I am slowly baginning to learn how to compose a picture much better than I was doing before. the difference between a snapshot and a good picture may be slight but but makes thi pic great. It's learning the how to take a better pic that makes it a lot of fun and interresting. I hope you have another workshop soon."
results.name: Outdoor Composition workshop

results.description:
Cape Ann and North Shore
Saturday - August 15

Ride Type: Cue Sheet, GPS

Times and Routes: 10:00 a.m. Long 64 miles, Med 45, Short 30

Leaders: Gardner Gray Jr.

Description: Our rides head out through Manchester-by-the-Sea and feature views of Hammond Castle and the Atlantic. We wind our way through Gloucester and onto the back roads of picturesque Rockport. After coming through Gloucester a second time, our 30 mile ride heads back to Manchester, our 45 and 64 mile rides head to Essex where I hope you will ride back roads that you may not have enjoyed in prior North Shore excursions and find a good seafood restaurant, such as Woodmans, for lunch.The 45 mile ride adds in a few more miles and has 3/4 mile of flat gravel roads that pass by beautiful ponds. If you do not want to ride on the gravel follow the 45 Alt route.The 64-mile ride adds in the hills of Little Neck in Ipswich that have spectacular views of the ocean along with the 3/4 mile of flat gravel Horsey Set roads in Hamilton. If you do not want to ride on the gravel, follow the 45 Alt route.All rides return through Manchester to the High School.

Start: Manchester-by-the Sea High School 36 Lincoln St Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA 01944

Directions: Take MA-128 N to School St in Manchester-by-the-Sea. Take exit 15 from MA-128 N. R onto School St for 0.5. L onto Lincoln St for 0.2.

More information and UPDATES: http://crw.org/rides/ride.php?id=77&year=2015
results.name: Cape Ann and North Shore

We will meet at 10:00 am at the Kayak rental location, do the paper work for rentals and be on the water by 10.30. This is also a scenic stretch of flat water with lots of wildlife along the river, you may bring your camera, but keep it safe from water.

We will plan to do about 1.5 - 2 hours, so if renting solo, it would be around $25.00pp, dual/shared ones would be 16.00pp. Do bring your license/ID, bottle(s) of water, suntan lotion / hat. After the trip, will plan to have lunch at Margaritas in Waltham overlooking the river.

Will limit total attendance between the two groups to keep group manageable.

results.description:
Hey, it's Josh

Don't you like helping people? 

Wouldn't you like to easily meet new people? 

Are you inherently a team leader? 

The Boston Volunteers, the well respected 501c3 nonprofit, is actively seeking two dedicated leaders to join our team. 

This is a great opportunity for you if you: 

1. Like organizing events

2. yearn to help more people

3. want to easily meet new people

As many of you know, we have more than 7,800+ Boston Volunteers. Most of our volunteer events fill up immediately and have long waiting lists. 

We need you! 

Join us for breakfast and learn more. 

Can't make this event? Still want to get more involved? Simply post on this wall. I'll email you. We'd love to chat with you! 

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org

Детский центр «Az-Book-Ah!» в городе Billerica, MA объявляет набор детей на[masked] учебный год. 

В нашем центре доступны классы Математики, Русского Языка, Чтения и Литературы, Изобразительного Искусства и Рукоделия, а также занятия для детей дошкольного возраста и класс по Истории Мировой Культуры. results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

results.description:
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/soldering-workshop-tickets-17814219811

Instructor: Mike Rushton

If you’ve never soldered before, this is the class for you! This course teaches through-hole (90% of electronic kits) soldering and is recommended for the beginner. This is a hands-on class where the students learn techniques to help them solder through-hole components. Soldering can be daunting for the first solder joint, then the 2nd solder joint is not so bad, and by the time you’ve assembled the blinky grid, you will be quite confident and proficient in basic soldering skills.

Classes take place at Lowell Makes. We provide all the tools, irons, solder, parts, and seats for up to 5 students.

The class is expected to take around 2 hours to complete, there is a buffer built in in case we go a bit longer.

Prerequisites: None! Just bring yourself. The class price includes the cost of the WeevilEye kit.

What to bring: Lowell Makes will provide all the tools, irons and solder.

Proceeds above will go to help support Lowell Makes.

results.description:
The Israelite nation was developing its own identity and culture, but they were on the brink of destruction. The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

This meet-up will be a casual 'bring-a-boxed-lunch' affair. We'll meet at my house in Rockport and discuss Heathen traditions: Blots, holidays, Sumbel, Runes and more. I'm not an expert, but I've been around the block, so come with questions and put on your thinking hats.

I'll message you my address if you decide to come.

results.description:
Social In Boston Presents:

BOSTON ROOF DECKS TOUR

The Summer of 2015 is going to be a great one for the members of Social In Boston! One part of what makes it so great is our weekly roof deck tour. Each and every Saturday we'll be visiting a different roof deck for food, drinks, relaxation, and socializing. Please the details carefully every week, as the details are going to change. Some venues have better times to visit than others, and as already stated, each week will be in a different location...

Our Thirteenth Stop...

The Whiskey Priest is an Irish restaurant and bar, located in the Seaport District. Situated directly on the water, this upscale restaurant offers the best of Ireland with it's unique GastroPub concept to include old Irish favorites and some treats that you may not have seen for a while. You will also enjoy an extensive selection of New World pub dining favorites.

Not forgetting your thirst, Whiskey Priest carries one of New England's largest collection of whiskeys, with over 100 of the best whiskeys from all over the world. There's also an eclectic selection of 32 draught beers, with many more available by the bottle.

Join us on the roof deck to eat lunch, relax, and savor an experience like no other!

On the menu: Click here for the menu.

GETTING THERE

The Whiskey Priest is at 150 Seaport Boulevard, Boston Ma, 02210.

Click here for <a>directions on Google</a>. The nearest T stops are South Station on the Red Line, and the Aquarium stop on the Blue Line. You can catch a Silver Line bus from South Station by getting on bus SL1 or SL2, or you can walk from the Aquarium stop.

Parking: There is on street parking if you can find it, otherwise, check this Google map for parking in the Seaport District.

See you there Socialites!

~Matt
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us on the Roof Deck! : )
results.name: Boston Roof Decks Tour #13: Whiskey Priest

results.description:
Come join us as we begin the planning process for our 2016 trip to Brazil.

See details/sign up for the trip at: http://www.meetup.com/BostonOnyxbirds/events/221468186/ and then come help us plan.

The initial thought is to visit Rio de Janeiro during the Paralympic Games in September 2016 (much cheaper than visiting during the Olympics but with much of the same experience).  We would also visit Salvador da Bahia, which is the center of the Afro-Brasilian culture.  As always, some members may opt for other destinations or experiences but it would be great if we could all come together in those two cities. 

In any case, we invite you to be part of the discussion/planning from the start!

We hope to see you there.

results.description:
Note: 

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php 

You can get help for the following Data Science Specialization Classes:  (from https://www.coursera.org/specialization/jhudatascience/1?utm_medium=courseDescripTop )

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

R Programming

Getting and Cleaning Data

Exploratory Data Analysis

Reproducible Research

Statistical Inference

Regression Models

Practical Machine Learning

Developing Data Products

Data Science Capstone

results.description:
“AngularJS is a structural framework for dynamic web apps. It lets you use HTML as your template language and lets you extend HTML's syntax to express your application's components clearly and succinctly. Angular's data binding and dependency injection eliminate much of the code you would otherwise have to write. And it all happens within the browser, making it an ideal partner with any server technology.”- https://docs.angularjs.org/guide/introduction

Here are the details:


1. WHAT: Learning trails - Web Development Technologies: AngularJS


2. WHEN: August 15th, 2015 (this Saturday) from 1:00 PM - 3: 00 PM


3. WHERE:

We'll meet at the Braintree Library in the small conference room upstairs:


Thayer Public Library
798 Washington Street
Braintree, MA

4. WHY: Improve our technical knowledge and network. (Bring your business cards!)

5. ToDo: Please review the following article:


https://docs.angularjs.org/guide/introduction

<a href="https://www.raspberrypi.org/"></a>

6. Format: Presentation, demonstration, programming and discussions. This is a techie-led event. Bring your laptops!

7. Misc: Bring others interested with you!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be waiting upstairs in the small conference room in the Children section. If you do not find us, ask the librarian about the small group meeting in the conference room upstairs.
results.name: Learning trails - Web Development Technologies: AngularJS

results.description:
This is the final showcase for Open Style Lab's summer program, which pairs teams of designers, engineers, and occupational therapists with clients who face daily dressing challenges due to disabilities. The teams will formally present their user-centric clothing solutions from 2-3 pm. The presentations will be followed by an exhibit period from 3-4 pm. While some solutions involve technology, others are relatively analog, but do present opportunity to integrate technology. This event will be an opportunity to meet with program participants who are looking to commercially launch their products, and generally learn more about design for disabilities in Boston.

MIT Museum entrance fee applies.

Read more on the website:
http://www.openstylelab.com/

Event flyer:
results.name: Open Style Lab Final Showcase

You can either use one of HATCH's kits for free and leave it behind when you're finished or pay a $4 materials fee due on the day of class (cash only). If you do not wish to purchase your kit the class is free.

We will be meeting at the Charles River on Soldiers Field Road. 

We'll start at 4 PM and we'll go a few hours. Please bring a drum if you have one. We'll have a few available. 

Donations will be $10.-

We are asking folks to chip in with some veggies, potato salad, chips, salsa, if anyone has a small- medium grill and someone else has charcoal and lighter fluid: we be havin ourselves a bar-b-que !! Alan, Fanta and Thierno

results.description:
Let's enjoy the summer!

Time to come together and to celebrate our community. This is a chance for everyone to socialize and let loose. Invite a friend, a partner, or a family member and bring a dish, a bottle, and a story.


WHAT TO EXPECT

We will provide some basic items for the barbecue. However, we are hoping and expecting this to be in the style of a potluck, with everyone bringing a dish or drink to be shared with everyone. More information about the event below.


Venue: The event will be in a spacious backyard in the Brighton neighborhood. It's accessible by bus (57, 86) and by the Green Line (Chiswick Road on the B branch). Some street parking is available.


Food and Drink: Please bring any dish that you would like, but please ensure food dishes are clearly marked so that we avoid any issues with allergies and dietary restrictions and preferences. We can assist with this. **Please answer the question to let us know about any food allergies or dietary restrictions when you RSVP.**


Entertainment: Everyone is welcome to bring with them any games or activities they'd like. If people are up for it, we may even have some time for people to perform. Let us know if you'd like to perform something.


ANSWERS TO POTENTIAL QUESTIONS:

• This event/barbecue is free and all are welcome.


• This event will not count for the discussion requirements of some meetups.

• There will be great vegan and vegetarian options.

• Alcoholic beverages are welcome and some will be provided.


• Accessibility information: the grassy backyard is accessible via the driveway on the right side of the house, which has a gradual slope.  If there's a car in the driveway, it could be difficult to get past it in a wheelchair.  (It's not our driveway, so we don't control if someone is parked there.)  Our apartment is on the first floor, with a high threshold and one step to get in.  We have no pets, and indoor cooling is only with fans.  We have a fair number of chairs, though not enough for everyone to sit (depending on the size of the group).  Please let us know if you have other needs.


If you have any other questions, please feel free to email Duney Roberts directly: [masked].
results.name: Summer Barbecue!

results.description:
oops. I kinda fell off the face of the earth again, now didn't I?

Hi all, so very sorry to have let several months pass since our last event, but I'm still making the slow adjustment to this new, travel-heavy job and it's had every weekend since May, and many weeknights as well, booked solid. I'm hoping to have this situation rectified soon, but I appreciate your continued patience and dedication to drinking whiskey (I hope you've all kept practicing in the meantime - don't get rusty).

With that in mind, I invite you all to join me at 'the Last Hurrah' for a late afternoon session of drinking whiskey (from their outstanding whiskey list) and giving me hell for disappearing again.

Please note that I will not be able to reserve us a table (they don't do it) so we're scheduled to arrive as they open their doors and if enough of us are there, we can grab a good table close to other tables in case late-comers show up.

Also please note that ***they won't be serving food*** as they only do cocktail service on Saturday, so please either eat beforehand (good idea), or plan on joining me for a bite afterwards when we wrap things up. Please note that they don't allow outside food, so cancel that idea if you were planning to smuggle in a sandwich (but know that I like where your head is at).

OK, I hope to see many of you there. Sorry for the short notice (I literally just got out of a travel plan for this weekend), and look out for a weeknight event very soon.

See you saturday!
results.name: Whiskey and the 'airing of the grievances' at The Last Hurrah

results.description:
Let's keep the summer fun going with a Hawaiian themed pool party!

Are you feeling like you need a topical getaway, but can't get away right now? Come to our Hawaiian Pool Party at BOKX 109 at Hotel Indigo in Newton. We will have leis, fun props, and entertaining and interactive games! This will be a great chance to reconnect with friends and make lasting friendships with new ones. And for those of you who are single, this is a great way to meet other singles.

The main event will start at 5 p.m. and go until whenever. Come at 5 p.m. or anytime afterwards. If you would like to swim, you can come earlier (arrive anytime between 11 a.m. and 4 p.m. and can use the pool for a $25 entry fee). There is no entry fee to come out by the pool after 4 p.m.

There is no charge for the event. There will be a hospitality room in the hotel that will have complimentary light bites, and beer/wine and drinks. Downstairs by the pool and bar, people can order and pay for a wide variety of food and drinks. 

For more information and for menus, etc., here is a link to the hotel/bar: http://bokx109prime.com/

This is a multi-meetup event. Adults only.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet us by the pool. Please call/text Deanna at 508-333-3191 with questions or information on how to find us.
results.name: Hawaiian Pool Party at Hotel Indigo! Let's Celebrate the Summer!

results.description:
The evening begins with a potluck at 5:30 pm. We will bless the food and begin eating at 5:45 PM. Bring a delectable dish and bring your own plate, bowl, utensils, mug and napkin.

The fire will begin in the tipi at approximately 6:45 pm. In the spirit of exchange, please bring something to share - chocolate, wood for the fire, songs, stories, poems.  Also, we suggest a $5 monetary donation (more if you can, less if you can't), and we will "pass the hat" at the fire - no amount is too small.

The Community Fire is a consecrated fire, and everyone who would like to will have the opportunity to give offerings to the fire in the tradition of the Huichol people. The significance of the offerings and the procedure for making offerings will be explained at the beginning of the fire. The Huichol have loaned this way of consecrating the Fire, but the Fire is non-denominational and open to everyone.

Fire is a spiritual presence that moves something in us.  Once we consecrate the fire, we engage in "fire work" - a process that begins to move the energetic blocks that keep us from living a balanced, joyful life. We share stories from our lives, as well as poems, music, humor, and other creative expression.  Community Fires are a simple, but powerful way to settle our mind and experience the wisdom of heart, and an opportunity to connect with each other. There’s sometimes drumming and singing, sometimes jokes, and always the opportunity to share and speak about what's most important to us in our lives. This is a safe place where you can be heard. All are welcome, no matter your background, belief, tradition or non-tradition. The fires are family-friendly and open to people of all ages.  Come share whatever needs to be spoken, and a willingness to listen from the heart. Come with your concerns, your stories, your gifts, your laughter as we connect with old friends and meet new ones, and begin to deepen into that sense of community that is so essential to support us through life.

Some people partake in the smoking of tobacco around the fire.  Tobacco is a sacred plant whose energy is very similar to the energy of Fire.  When smoked consciously and with intention tobacco fosters connection with Fire and Heart.  To accommodate both tobacco smokers and those not smoking tobacco, a portion of the space around the fire circle will be designated as a non-smoking section, and another portion as the smoking section.

For more information about the Sacred Fire Community organization, check out http://sacredfirecommunity.org/

After you RSVP I will email you the address of the Community Fire and some useful landmarks.

See you around the Fire!
results.how_to_find_us: Directions will be emailed after you RSVP
results.name: Community Fire and Potluck

results.description:
This will be a host less event, I've been here before and the fire throwing show is AWESOME..... So you guys can pick a spot to mix and mingle together Have Fun!!!!

To celebrate the Union Square's sizzling food landscape we bring you our latest Arts Union event: Ignite, an evening of fire throwers, international eats, roving entertainment and a raucous celebration of global culture.

Just a few of the 2015 vendors are Cantina La Mexicana, Casa B (Latin American Tapas), Reliable Market (Korean), India Palace, Gracie’s Ice Cream and the Arts Council’s Nibble Culinary Entrepreneurs, who will be serving up: Mexican Tostadas de Tinga de Pollo and Brazilian Acarajé. You’ll also be able to graze on Brazilian BBQ while sipping freshly squeezed sugar cane juice, or perhaps a vegetarian Indian dosa is more up your alley? Options will abound. Head behind the Independent to the MUSCRAT food court to enjoy your fare. Then step into the Uniun where there will be a DJ and activities for all ages.

Looking to not just eat food but interact with it? Step on over to the Arts Council table to play Ignite Your Mouth or the Nose Olympics! While there, check out the SAC’s Nibble book, which is filled with recipes, stories and delicious art. Nearby there will be food demos: Mexican Cactus Juice, Brazilian Acarajé and a how-to ferment extravaganza. There also will be activities for children (6-8), including a Play with your Food! art activity. Also swing by the tables of local organizations Groundworks Somerville and the Community Growing Center to learn more about their great food-related work. Adding to the night bazaar ambiance, there will be roving performers, including belly dancers, Butoh cheerleaders and musicians. Get ready for a salsa lesson and, of course don’t miss the main event: a fire throwing spectacular by Boston Circus Guild. The festival will be illimunated in high style courtesy of Todd Sargent. From the global menu and fire throwing to an 8 foot tiger head created by Pecan Nut, this festival guarantees thrills, international flavor — and a full stomach!

Rain date: Sunday, August 16
results.how_to_find_us: In the square
results.name: Ignite!!! Global Food Festival

results.description:
This will be a host less event, I've been here before and the fire throwing show is AWESOME..... So you guys can pick a spot to mix and mingle together Have Fun!!!!

To celebrate the Union Square's sizzling food landscape we bring you our latest ArtsUnion event: Ignite, an evening of fire throwers, international eats, roving entertainment and a raucous celebration of global culture.

Just a few of the 2015 vendors are Cantina La Mexicana, Casa B (Latin American Tapas), Reliable Market (Korean), India Palace, Gracie’s Ice Cream and the Arts Council’s Nibble Culinary Entrepreneurs, who will be serving up: Mexican Tostadas de Tinga de Pollo and Brazilian Acarajé. You’ll also be able to graze on Brazilian BBQ while sipping freshly squeezed sugar cane juice, or perhaps a vegetarian Indian dosa is more up your alley? Options will abound. Head behind the Independent to the MUSCRAT food court to enjoy your fare. Then step into the Uniun where there will be a DJ and activities for all ages.

Looking to not just eat food but interact with it? Step on over to the Arts Council table to play Ignite Your Mouth or the Nose Olympics! While there, check out the SAC’s Nibble book, which is filled with recipes, stories and delicious art. Nearby there will be food demos: Mexican Cactus Juice, Brazilian Acarajé and a how-to ferment extravaganza. There also will be activities for children (6-8), including a Play with your Food! art activity. Also swing by the tables of local organizations Groundworks Somerville and the Community Growing Center to learn more about their great food-related work. Adding to the night bazaar ambiance, there will be roving performers, including belly dancers, Butoh cheerleaders and musicians. Get ready for a salsa lesson and, of course don’t miss the main event: a fire throwing spectacular by Boston Circus Guild. The festival will be illimunated in high style courtesy of Todd Sargent. From the global menu and fire throwing to an 8 foot tiger head created by Pecan Nut, this festival guarantees thrills, international flavor — and a full stomach!

Rain date: Sunday, August 16
results.name: Ignite!!! A Global Food Festival

results.description:
Saturday Night Sit is a community meditation practice group, peer facilitated and free to all. Group sittings are held Saturday nights from 6:30pm to 7:45pm at Karma Yoga Studio on Newbury St. in Boston, MA above Trident Cafe. We meditate together to explore and expand upon our meditation practice. Sits begin with a guided meditation, followed by a short talk and group discussion. Donations accepted to cover space rental.

No meditation experience, religious affiliation, or anything else required...All you need to do is show up.

All are welcome.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/saturdaynightsit
results.name: Saturday Night Sit

results.description:
We will journey inward in a time-honored shamanic method of inner consultation. It is a way of communicating with your inner or spirit self and retrieving information. Your inner self is in constant communication with all aspects of your environment, seen and unseen. You need only journey within to find answers to your questions. Be prepared, however, for whatever insights you may receive, whether you like them or not.
The spirit healing journey is not always what people expect, and sometimes there is uncertainty as to what one should experience in altered states. The ecstatic trance is an individual journey into non-ordinary reality; therefore, experiences vary from person to person and from journey to journey. Once you enter a trance state, the rhythm or sound of the drum tends to change. The drumbeat may appear to speed up or slow down, while the sound may grow louder, softer, or disappear. You may experience a change in body temperature, feel energy flowing through your body, or find yourself twitching, swaying, or rocking. It is not uncommon to hear sounds or voices. You may even smell specific aromas. You may see colorful patterns, symbolic images, or dreamlike visions. Some people may find that they have a highly developed inner vision while others may rely more on instinct, intuition, or intent.
During the spirit healing journey, one's awareness transcends ordinary reality. In journeys to the Lower World, one may experience the sensation of falling, sliding, or spiraling downward into or under the Earth. In Upper World journeys, one may experience the sensation of rising, floating, flying, or spiraling upward through the air or sky. Journeys to the Lower World involve the movement of awareness to a level beneath ordinary reality and Celestial journeys involve movement to a level above ordinary reality. Lower levels are denser, lower in frequency, and more involved with the physical body, the earthly plane, and material reality. Higher levels are higher in frequency, less dense, and subtler.
You will experience at least two spiritual journeys. You do not need prior journeying experiences but an openness of the process and possibilities. Elaine is a training and practicing Shaman and will safely lead you on your journey. Please bring a yoga mat, blanket, something to cover your eyes (scarf), and journal as you may wish to write your experiences immediately following the journey. $10 Any questions or to register please contact Elaine [masked] or[masked]
results.name: An Evening of Shamanic Spiritual Healing

results.description:
THIRD MAN ADVANCED TICKETS

Naïve American pulp novelist Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten) arrives in the morally ambiguous world of divided, crumbling post-war Vienna to take a job from a friend, but is shocked to find that he has been killed in a car accident. Martins suspects foul play and sets out to discover the identity of the “third man,” the mysterious witness to the incident, who is the person he hopes can reveal the true story. Shot in breathtaking black and white, with inky shadows that hide lurking figures, the film climaxes in an unforgettable chase through the labyrinthine underground sewers. Orson Welles, in relatively little screen time, dominates the film as the mesmerizing mystery man Harry Lime. Co-starring Trevor Howard and Alida Valli. Famed novelist Graham Greene adapted the dramatic screenplay from his own story; Carol Reed (Odd Man Out, The Fallen Idol, Oliver!) masterfully directed. Digitally restored by Deluxe Restoration, on behalf of Studiocanal, from a fine grain master positive struck from the original negative.

100% RATING ON ROTTEN TOMATOES.  ICONIC PERFORMANCE BY ORSON WELLES.

See you at the Movie,

John
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meetup after End of Credits in the lobby area near the Ticket Taker and go to our designated outdoor reserved table at the CBC for sup and discupssion.
results.name: THE THIRD MAN

results.description:
Created by ancient Indian rishis from Vedic mantras, kirtan is a yoga of sound - an evening of beautiful music and heartfelt call-and-response singing. No previous experience is necessary to experience its emotional depth, yet powerful as it is, kirtan is effortless and incredibly enjoyable. Freely offered ~ please make a donation!

Shubalananda (Larry Kopp) has been leading kirtan for many years, having studied with Neem Karoli Baba, Sathya Sai Baba, Karunamayi and Shree Maa. His guitar & harmonium playing and voice of experience gives his kirtan a power and a heartfulness that is shared with all who join in. Find out more at www.shubalananda.com
results.name: Kirtan Concert with Shubalananda plus special guests

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Please be sure to bring socks with you in order to play!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the only ones there, you'll see us! :) Together In Motion is the name of the place.
results.name: Dodge The Ball! - Play Dodgeball With Us!

results.description:
Four gifted and accomplished guitarists who are sure to wow us with an dynamic blend of sound and styles for a great summer night.

Steve Marchena
An established favorite of Dedham and Boston, Steve has the talent, diversity, energy and soul to always delight an audience. “Marchena’s blazing guitar and perfect rhythm playing are nothing less than stunning. ” - Pat Keating, Insite Boston.

German Schauss
Among his many accomplishments, German uses odd and even meters to fuse the classical influences of Bach, Beethoven and Chopin with modern instrumental rock guitar music through epic music structures and lush soundscapes.

John Paolilli
John was voted WMRC "best guitarist" in the year 2012. He played in a Heineken commercial, and has recorded guitars for major label artists. Additionally, he plays over 150 shows a year with several bands. Check him out.

Patrick DeCoste
“Like U2 but with Van Halen-esque solos”: That’s how the media has described the instrumental rock of guitarist Patrick DeCoste. In the great tradition of Stevie Ray Vaughan and Jeff Beck, DeCoste combines virtuoso skills with rock and roll attitude to create his own unique sound. He’s got the chops to play in the orchestra pit for the Grammy-winning musical HAIRSPRAY, and the swagger to play his own original interpretation of the Star Spangled Banner at Shea Stadium. http://www.thebostoncalendar.com/events/four-guitarists-one-night

Saturday Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party on Saturdays featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away!

9:00-10:00pm:  Beginner & Intermediate. Salsa Lessons
10:00-2am: Dance Party * No Partner Required

Lets meet 15 minutes before the dance lesson at 8:45pm at (facing the stage) at the right side of the stage.

There are some tables alongside the wall. These tables are typically first come, first serve, so if we all arrive at the same time and early, we can occupy these tables.

I will make some Meetup signs and try to post them at these tables.  These tables can serve as our meeting point through out the night.

I also have some neon/glow-in-the-dark bracelets and necklaces that I plan to wear and pass out to members of the group so we can recognize each other more easily.

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 

Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds.

This should be a super fun event and a super friendly event for salsa beginners and the advanced dancers.


I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.

Wear comfortable shoes!

Joana

******************************************************************************************************************************

Event Details

Beginners Very Welcome

No partner required

$12 - Admission includes lesson and party

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant (No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)

Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar

Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 10% merengue/cha cha

***********************************
Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St.

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr)parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk.

Please note that the Night Salsa parties are 21+.

* Don't forget your ID!

http://www.havanaclubsalsa.com/salsa_saturdays.shtml
results.how_to_find_us: Right side of the stage at 8:45pm sharp! Meetup signs at the tables on the right side (facing stage) , nearest the stage.  Also look for Glow-in-Dark bracelets and necklaces!
results.name: Lets Dance Salsa!  at the Havana Club in Central Square! Lesson Included!

You've seen Kevin Quigley's hilarious storytelling show, Wild Memory Nation, all over Boston: Johnny D's Comedy Presents, Phoenix Landing Comedy Presents, ImprovBoston SketchHaus, even in a featured slot at the Women in Comedy Festival. Now see what happens when the funniest true stories get the late night treatment ... and get a little bit naughty.

NIGHT MOVES features some of the best comedians telling the funniest stories about the most ticklish subject of all: sex. From sex-positive hilarity to the most intimate of disasters, NIGHT MOVES brings you the saucy side of Boston comedy. True sex stories, real funny. Only $12! Only at ImprovBoston!

Your 8/15 lineup: Jordan Handren-Seavey, Matt Kona, Owen Linders, Chukwunonyerem Orikaba Egedeyeob-Orikadibia (Nonye Brown-West), James Huessy, Casey Stoddard, & Jere Pilapil!

venue.name: Dolan Center Launch (Dedham Parks and Recreation)

results.description:
Paddle the 6.5-mile loop on the Charles River in Dedham, MA. I urge you to go to http://dedhamtrails.com/ and learn about the trail before you go. 

We will start at the Dolan Center Launch, 269 Common Street, Dedham, MA.  The launch is quiet, kayak/canoe friendly and there is ample parking.  The signs actually call it the ‘Dedham Parks and Recreation Complex.”  If you miss the first entrance there is another just a short ways along.  From there we will follow the water loop counterclockwise.  There are ample opportunities to take breaks along the way.  I expect this will take us three to four hours.  Pack snacks and drink to your liking please.  The current is helpful and the paddling will be easy.  We can expect at least one short, flat portage of about 20 yards where the ‘Long Ditch’ rejoins the river at Needham Street, and other places where it may be so shallow we have to walk.

Meet at 9 am sharp.  We will launch when everyone is ready.

If you are running late, call my cell phone[masked]-0528.  We will wait for latecomers, IF you call.

Some ‘to bring’ suggestions:

1.  Plenty to drink.  We’re going to be out for up to four hours. 

2.  Water shoes.  Most of you use them I know, but want to make sure.  I know of at least one place we’ll be wading or portaging in shallow water/rocks and there might be others.

3.  Food.  There will be ample opportunities to stop and snack along the way, but we won’t be very close to places you can go and buy something.

4.  A whistle.  Use it if you need assistance.

5.  PFD, bring it and wear it please.

6.  A line for your canoe or kayak.  A ten-foot length of just about any kind of rope tied to an end of your boat will come in handy if we have to walk through any shallow spots where the boats can float.

7.  A poncho if you like in case of rain.

A word about portaging.  I intend for portages to be communal in nature.  They should be a spot for regrouping, so no one leaves a portage until everyone is through.  If you can do the portage without help, fine.  Others may need help though, so please be willing to pitch in.  And don’t let all this scare you.  I’m not into hard work either.

I’m not a fanatic about always staying clumped together, but I will insist that this be a leisurely group ride.  To that end there are four places where we will stop and regroup along the way, to make sure everyone’s OK.  These will be our snack stops too, most likely.  These stops will be at No. 4, the town landing (1.5 miles from launch, No. 11, Kehoe Park (2 miles from 1st stop), No. 13, the top of the Long Ditch (1 mile from last stop) and at the Needham Street Bridge, portage spot at bottom of the Ditch, which is a half mile long.  From there it is about 1.5 miles back to our start point.

Remember, do your homework.  Check this place out at http://dedhamtrails.com/.

***PLEASE NOTE*** The organizers in this group are NOT trained leaders or instructors.  The organizers only set the time and place, each person participating in any group trip is responsible for their own safety.  Each participant is responsible for evaluating all relevant conditions for the trip and determining if their skills and equipment are appropriate for those conditions.

Liability Release – AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, you agree to hold harmless and indemnify the organizer and their heirs, and all members and participants of this MeetUp group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial and/or other risk associated with this MeetUp. All MeetUp activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment.


Required: PFD (worn), whistle, headlamp/flashlight (evening paddles). Optional/recommended: pump/bailer, insect repellent, sunscreen, water, snack, change of clothes in drybag, sunglasses, hat/visor.

In areas where there is a boat launch intended to be used by people with trailers, please, if possible, launch to the side of the ramp and do not block the ramp with your kayak or other belongings.
results.name: Paddle the Dedham Water Trail in Dedham, MA

venue.name: Dolan Center Launch (Dedham Parks and Recreation)

results.description:
The Boston Harbor Islands national recreation area includes 34 islands and peninsulas spread over fifty square miles of bays, harbors, and rivers within the greater Boston Harbor basin. The Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR, Mass Parks) is one of twelve managing partners and owns and manages more than half of the islands in the park. We will be visiting Georges and Lovells Islands on this visit.

Since we will be exposed for much of the day, sunblock is highly recommended.  Bring a lunch for stop on Georges Island.

There will be many photo opportunities!   Because the ferry stops at a few islands, the first hour will be a scenic boat ride by numerous islands until we arrive at Georges  at 11:30.

Price is $17 and $12 for seniors.

The boat will leave Hull at 10:10 and return from the islands at 4:50.  

Boat does only have a capacity of 49 people, so arriving early is critical and admission is on a first come/first serve basis. It is strongly suggested you arrive early (9:15)to purchase a ticket.

Here is a link with more information island information, including island maps: http://www.bostonharborislands.org/

More details:


Ferry to leave Hull at 10:10 with stops at Bumpkin and Peddocks Islands before arriving at Georges Island at 11:30 

Georges Island has Fort Warren as centerpiece and also has a museum with exhibits,  and refreshments.  

Leave Georges at 1:30 for ferry to Lovells Island where we will arrive at 1:40.  
We will be given a guided tour by Rab Sherman of the Friends of Boston Harbor Islands.

Leave Lovells at 3:55 and arrive back in Hull at 4:50.

Please note that there will by a combined 2.5 hours ferry time as part of this outing.  Lovells Island has limited shade, so sunblock is highly recommended.
results.how_to_find_us: Pemberton Point Terminal is at the tip of the Hull peninsula. Parking is free at ferry parking lot and also at nearby Hull High School.
results.name: Boston Harbor Islands - Georges and Lovells Island Tour

For those hardy souls who would like to paint a male model for four weeks (it's generally been females during the year), this session will run the four Sundays in August.  We'll need five paying members to run it, so please don't hesitate- you'll have the studio to yourselves and do a long- term complex set up that won't be disturbed.  Our member Lai-Hew will lead the sessions.  

$60 members, $70 non-members (members are those who, by virtue of their unyielding support of the BFAC, have paid their membership during our quiet August)

If you haven't paid the membership, feel free to email to me at [masked], or through meetup rather then pay the membership to RSVP to meetup.   I need to know you're coming so we know we've got enough to run the sessions.  

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting).
