venue.name: Meriam Street Municipal Lot

results.description:
Annual Al Bolea Memorial Ride


9:30 for 20, 38 or 53 miles 

More details on the CRW Calendar: http://bit.ly/Iw67FE

Description:

This always popular ride is to remember Al Bolea, a prominent CRW member, who lost a long battle with a degenerative bone marrow disease, and encourage donations to the MPN Research Foundation. We offer routes which travel scenic back roads of Concord, Acton, Carlisle, and Bedford, and even include a lemonade stand. The long ride will also visit scenic Boxborough and Littleton.

This is the arrow to follow for the ride:

This is a re-occuring ride every Sunday beginning in April, with the organized and marked rides of CRW (Charles River Wheelmen). The picture above is from one of last years rides. Don't let the # of RSVPs here fool you, these rides are always well atended usually with over 25 riders of all abilities.

The distances and routes vary every week. We'll have "No Drop Rule" so you won't have to worry about getting lost or keeping up. Ride with us if you ride anywhere from 15 to 20 MPH.

Always bring two spare tubes, and your preferred hydration and nutrition. We don't typically stop for lunch but depending on the ride, there are sometimes options to stop for a bit. Before riding it's good practice to get your bike tuned. Remember to dress for the elements.

Also CRW organizes a Spring Century, a Summer Century called Climb to the Clouds, and a Fall Century. All of the Centuries have organized food and water stops. I'm hoping to get a group committed to building up to these Century rides.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for EH riding Jerseys
results.name: Weekly Sunday Bike Ride

results.description:
This Sunday is your chance to photograph  the SoWa Scene! Join the fun and learn new photography skills to improve your photos on the spot.


http://newenglandopenmarkets.com/southend/   You can check out the event on their website. 


Photo of dog attending SoWa. If you don't want to photograph people go for the dogs. They love the market and are happy to pose for you.

Sundays in SoWa became a big hit eleven years ago with the beginning of the SoWa Open Market – an open air crafts and art market showcasing handmade goods by talented small business owners. Founded by Chris Masci and NE Open Markets, LLC. The Market continues to grow, now filling three parking lots at 460, 500 and 540 Harrison Ave, showcasing vendors from all over New England and beyond. The SoWa Open Market, the SoWa Vintage Market, SoWa Food Truck Court and the SoWa Farmers Market. Together, these five weekly markets make SoWa Sundays!

SoWa is the cultural district in Boston located South of Washington Street, which is where it gets its name.

SoWa Food Trucks

 Sunday there is a fantastic event in the Boston South End. The SoWa Open Market. I will be leading a workshop on the spot to discover secrets of how to photograph festivals and events. Some topics we will cover: How to take action shots, how to cut out clutter, how to photograph food trucks, street scenes,  people and dogs. Composition is the key.

Noticing the details Photo by previous workshop participant Vicky. 

In this fun and educational event, you'll discover  techniques that improve every single photo you take from now on. Bring your iPhone, Point and Shoot or DSLR. All levels welcome to participate in this workshop.

• How to be confident about where to place the subject for the greatest impact.

• How to use aperture or shutter priority to make sure your photos are in focus and properly exposed.

• How to use basic design principles to add visual interest and creativity to your photos.

• How to be more comfortable photographing people on the street. 

 The techniques you learn in this workshop can easily be transferred to your next travel adventure.


SoWa Vintage Market If you like antiques and flea markets check this part out.

Events can be visually chaotic. As the photographer, you need to hone your skill of isolating key elements and bringing our attention to one thing at a time using color composition, lighting etc. This makes a more powerful image. Then, several images in a sequence can add up to a photo essay that tells the story of the day.


Photo by former workshop participant Charlene great use of shallow depth of field and composition. Photographed in the farmers market area

SoWa Farmers Market

I have designed three photo assignments for you that will build your skills of photographing dynamic, colorful, events and festivals. These skills are perfect for travel photography, and for preparing for the summer ahead here in Boston where there will be special events, parades and block parties nearly every weekend from now on. 

Photo by former participant Jaimin in the artist market area. Great use of color to tell a story and isolate a subject. 

We will meet at 450 Harrison Ave. I will introduce the workshop topics. Then we will walk together to the Market location so you can do your first assignment. Next we will meet again every 45 minutes to review photos and get an introduction to the next skill and practice assignment for that skill. 

The class runs from 9:30-12:30 and you can continue to shoot after the class since the market is open until 4:00

Join us to learn, have fun, meet great people and take better pictures this Sunday. Tuition for the workshop is $30.00.

results.description:
I am trying out this class for the first time hence the low price. It's a day for creating one absolutely stunning photograph.  

What is it about? 

We will meet at the studio for an introductory session in which I will explain a proven approach to creating a strong image, we will then travel to a local destination where you will put the approach into practice by creating a single photograph. 

Returning to the studio in the afternoon we will analyze our single image and look at post-processing it using a combination of Lightroom and Photoshop. 

What will you get out of this workshop

The aim is for you to walk away with a strong image to add to your portfolio. 

However, the process of achieving that aim is likely to prove more informative and valuable than the finished product.

During the day you will be forced to slow down and put into practice a series of steps that will definitely improve your way of seeing and composing the potential shot.

Who will benefit from this?

Anyone who has a reasonable grasp of their camera control, and who is looking for a better approach to creating strong photographs. 

The class will run from 10am to 5pm and because you will be guinea pigs for this experimental class the cost will be just $49.
results.name: The Expert Session: One day- one image!

results.description:
Were restarting the session curriculum, so if you haven't come before heres a perfect first session!! Those who have been in attendance will be put on an advanced track for the session.

This weeks session is wall tek, getting over, off and to walls.

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
This social activity is completely voluntary, and not-for-profit: no compensation of any kind is required or expected for participation. By boarding my boat, you explicitly agree to assume full personal responsibility for your own safety and well-being, and indemnify me against any legal liability.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sailing Info 

Please read disclaimer at the bottom of the page before you RSVP

Who can come
Everybody is invited.
I will be skippering the boat in and out of the mooring field and will be taking over when needed. Once we are in clear waters we will be taking turns at the tiller.


Where
We will be sailing in the Boston inner harbor, and might venture out and sail around one of the Boston Harbor Islands.


What 

- we will sail on
Boston 27 (Based on Soling) , Sonar, or Soling. You can learn more about these boats here: http://www.bostonharborsailing.com/fleet_boston27.html


- to expect
A laid back and safe sailing adventure to the extent it is possible on the racing boat without the engine or bathroom in the busy harbor.

In perfect conditions Boston 27 is a comfortable boat to sail on, but in the strong winds boat will lean and you might get splashed. On a windy day be prepared to pull on the ropes, move around, get splashed, and not have much down-time.

Be warned that it can get stressful at times and we will need to react quickly. . Remember, these boats don’t have engines and we will have to rely on the wind power. During stressful situations it is important to stay calm and to work as a team.

- will be on the boat
Two flotation pillows and four life jackets.


- is important
Safety will be our number one priority. I will give a safety crash course once we are on the boat. I recommend that everyone wears a life jacket.


- to bring
Sunscreen, hat, sunglasses, water, and a cell phone. Sailing Boston 27 or Soling on a windy day can get you splashed. I would recommend bringing a change of clothes and getting a waterproof case for you cell phone or wrapping it in a plastic bag.


- I will bring
My own gear, two-way UHF floating radio pre-programmed with the sailing club and Coast Guard channels and a winch handle to help tighten the sails.


Disclaimer
Sailing can be and will be stressful at times.
It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is part of the sport.

results.description:
DATE;

***SUNDAY***

Sunday August 16th. For this one month we will meet on Sunday.

BOOK:

The Ever After of Ashwin Rao by Padma Viswanathan

This is by the author of The Toss of a Lemon, a group favorite.


DESCRIPTION:

From internationally acclaimed New Face of Fiction author Padma Viswanathan, a stunning new work set among families of those who lost loved ones in the 1985 Air India bombing, registering the unexpected reverberations of this tragedy in the lives of its survivors. A book of post-9/11 Canada, The Ever After of Ashwin Rao demonstrates that violent politics are all-too-often homegrown in North America but ignored at our peril.
 In 2004, almost 20 years after the fatal bombing of an Air India flight from Vancouver, 2 suspects--finally--are on trial for the crime. Ashwin Rao, an Indian psychologist trained in Canada, comes back to do a "study of comparative grief," interviewing people who lost loved one in the attack. What he neglects to mention is that he, too, had family members who died on the plane. Then, to his delight and fear, he becomes embroiled in the lives of one family caught in the undertow of the tragedy, and privy to their secrets. This surprising emotional connection sparks him to confront his own losses. The Ever After of Ashwin Rao imagines the lasting emotional and political consequences of a real-life act of terror, confronting what we might learn to live with and what we can live without.

results.name: AUGUST: Ever After of Ashwin Rao by Padma Viswanathan at Singh's Cafe-Wellesley

(Credit to Francesco Cardiello for the information below):
BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!
If you are looking for a partner or just want to get your climb on join us on Wednesdays for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to top rope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. The Wednesday meetup assures you'll meet a partner to regularly climb with. We are looking to expand to other nights in the future.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): Day Pass - $25 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
The race to be Number One has been called America's state religion. We've been trained not only to compete frantically, but to believe in the value of beating people -- and to help our children become winners. Research and experience, however, demonstrate that competition is actually destructive to self-esteem, poisonous to relationships, and counterproductive in terms of achievement -- at work and at school. The result is that everyone ultimately loses in the desperate race to win. If we as humanists are committed to the value of collaboration and community, then it's important to question assumptions about the value (or inevitability) of competition that are sometimes taken on faith even by those who prefer to rely on reason.

Alfie Kohn is the author of 14 books about education, parenting, and human behavior. These include Punished by Rewards, The Myth of the Spoiled Child, The Brighter Side of Human Nature, and his first book, No Contest: The Case Against Competition. He has been described as the country's leading critic of competition, although he notes that there isn't much competition for that title. Kohn lectures to researchers, parents, teachers, and managers all over the world. He lives (actually) in Belmont and (virtually) at 

www.alfiekohn.org.
results.name: Alfie Kohn: No Contest: Moving from Competition to Cooperation

results.description:
Nectar is a talk-free dance inspired by conscious and ecstatic dance. It is a space to enjoy and explore embodiment, physical expression, and the body’s wisdom. After an unguided warm-up period, the Facilitator-DJ leads a brief opening circle on a theme or guided practice, followed by a playlist of music—beginning spacious and mellow, gaining intensity, and arriving back into stillness. Participants are welcome to move, dance, and be still as their bodies desire. Nectar closes with a sharing circle in which participants are welcome to speak about their experiences in the dance.

Nectar is offered primarily for adults. Children are welcome with adult accompaniment provided they can follow the talk-free and intentional structure and be mindful of their impact on others in the space. Kids under 6 can come for free, and ages 6-12 for half price ($5-7). $10-15 for adults.

Nectar was created by Amorn O’Connor and Harrison Blum, and is supported by a rotating crew of Facilitator-DJs.

Please note that many more people attend than RSVP via Meetup!

Distance to car:4 There's a 200 foot walk through the woods

Parking availability: 5 Although the Stone Zoo can get busy, I've never seen anyone deprived of a space.

Bathroom availability: 3 The Stone Zoo has bathrooms, though it's 1/4 mile walk.

Hey guys, I asked to be in charge of the August Meetup since I've been really itching to play 18EU, which I spent days cutting out and now possess. If we get enough interest (6+) we can have two tables and bring other 18xx games into the mix. I've set the date as the 16th as it's the only day I'm sure I can make it. Early RSVPS are helpful (obviously not required).

I really want to encourage people to come, including people new to 18xx and/or GBCC. I'll be there early to teach (and I happen to think 18EU is more newbie - friendly than other 18xx games while still providing a lot of strategic flexibility).

18xx games are railroad building and stock trading games with common core mechanics but also specific features for each. 18EU follows the history of rails in Europe as players begin with minor regional railroads that merge to form national (and finally international) corporations.

--------------------------

About 334 Mass Ave:

When you arrive, press 999 on the intercom, so security can let you in.  Sign in with a picture id at security and tell them you're going to level A.  Take the elevator down to level A. The community room is to the right of the laundry room.

I suggest you take the T, if possible.  The Green E line Symphony stop is under the building or across the street; you can also exit other Green lines at Hynes. The Orange line Mass Ave stop is a block away. The #39 bus stops at Gainsborough and Huntington. The #1 and BU shuttle buses stop in front of the building.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack

results.description:
</a>

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

<a href="https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com">https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com


(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>
results.name: Speeddating Ages 30-42 - SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

group.name: And That's Why You're Single Events - Boston

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Here is how it works..

-Upon arrive you will be given a name tag with your code name and number..

-You will also be given a sheet where you can keep track of everyone you meet.

-We will have an ice breaker games throughout the night where you will have a chance to meet others at the event and write down the code names and numbers of those you wish to make a connection with.

-At the end of the night write down the names and the numbers of the people that you met and would like to see again.  You will then hand in your sheet and we will send you the contact info for all the people who have a mutual match with you! The Night Will Feature:

Ice Breaker game with prizes -Full menu is available (pay as you go)  -Music played at conversational levels

 What are the age ranges? This event will cater mostly to 20's-late 30's's.

results.description:
For the 180th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :8/16@6:30

venue.address_1: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 2 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

results.description:
Let's join five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

This is offered FREE OF CHARGE as a community service
results.name: Sunday Night Meditation

results.description:
Okay word nerds, this is going to be an open ended thing. Let's get together and talk about words and language. What's your favorite or most surprising etymology? Favorite new declaration by the OED that it's an official word now? Do verbing and abusages like 'irregardless' drive you crazy? Who gets to define what's acceptable in language? Should we accept the role of lexicographer as 'reporter of usage', or should some defining sensibilities carry some kind of weight in how we speak and write? Is it really such a big deal so long as people know what one another are talking about, or do we lose something if we do not embrace tradition in language?

To get us started, here's language historian Anne Curzan on what makes a word real:

http://www.ted.com/talks/anne_curzan_what_makes_a_word_real


So get out your mental dictionaries and grammar books, and join us in a fun discussion about the intricacies, idiosyncrasies, and evolution of our language.

Hope to see you there :)
results.name: Words Words Words

results.description:
There is nothing more wonderful than a nice stroll through Boston on a summer day, that is, unless you add food and wine! 

This fabulous 

2 hour guided walking tour

 stops at fine Boston restaurants and wine stores to teach you how to buy wines, find hidden gems and 

educate you in the fine art of wine tasting and food pairing

. While enjoying your food and wine, you will even learn a bit of Boston history.

This 

Wine & Food Walking Tour 

generally includes:


Tastings of 6 delicious wines, paired up with food.Learning how to taste wine. 

2-3 tour stops

 including a variety of restaurants.A chance to explore Boston's vibrant culture


with a local guide.

Our first stop

 on the tour is Pasta Beach, a classic Italian restaurant, which offers a great wine list and delicious food. This restaurant sits on the cusp of Boston Harbor. 

Our second stop

 is Tamo Bistro & Bar. You will embark on a scenic walk, which takes us up Sea Port Lane to a beautiful hotel. Here we will sample delicious wine and food pairings while enjoying views of the harbor.

Our third stop

 is either Salvatore's, or J Pace Wine Shop. This stop takes us further up the sea port where we learn how to pair wine with Italian dishes.

Learn how to taste, pour and pair wine, join us today for a memorable tour!
results.name: Waterfront wine tour

results.description:
Moderate paced 36/47 mile ride starting in Hingham. 24 miles will be along the scenic coast and beaches of Scituate and Cohasset and Hull. Those interested in more swimming (or shorter ride) can skip Hull and spending time at Sandy Beach.

If you are interested, you will need a working bike, spare tire, bike helmet, bright clothes and sun block. Swim suit and towel optional. You will also need cash for ice cream stops and lunch. The map link show our four stops where we will regroup.

Ride starts at 9:00 AM. http://ridewithgps.com/routes/2911831

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

I borrowed the book  "Think & Grow Rich" from a good friend and just finished it.  I loved it so much I went to B&N to purchase my own copy to re-read and put more time into the work assignments and was pleased to find they have a workbook to supplement the original book.  

There are 14 Chapters to this amazing book:

Desire, Faith, Auto Suggestion, Specialized Knowledge, Imagination, Organized Planning, Decision, Persistence, Power of the Master Mind, They Mystery of Sex Transmutation, The Subconscious Mind, The Brain, The Sixth Sense and How to Outwit the Six Ghosts of Fear

While this book title is  about "Growing Rich" in terms of money it also helps with Growing Rich in terms of living a full filling happy life:)

B&N offers a "Master Mind Volume and workbook set for $29.99 or you can just pick up the the original copy for under $8.00 

We will cover a Chapter per month and thoroughly discuss it, share with each other and learn from one another.

This is a food establishment, a food purchase is required:)

Please no perfumes or fragrances, we have members with allergies.

Please be respectful of the Organizers who put time and effort into posting and hosting events.  If you RSVP for an event, please plan on showing up for that event.  Same day cancellations WILL count as  no show.

results.description:
(Prefer the original cover to the repackaged look.)

Our pick:

Sabriel by Garth Nix is the first book in the Old Kingdom series. (However, the book basically functions as a stand alone novel because it was originally written as such and the next in the series focus on other characters and expanding the world.) The Old Kingdom is a land of Free Magic that exists across the border of Ancelstierre, a modern land where technology functions and magic does not work except near the Wall when the wind blows from the North.


Eighteen-year-old Sabriel is her last year at Wyverley College, an all-girl’s boarding school in Ancelstierre near the Wall of the Old Kingdom. Her father is the Abhorsen, a highly skilled necromancers who fights the dead who seek to return to Life, and Sabriel is the Abhorsen-in-Waiting. Sabriel has been stashed across the Wall for over a decade to protect her and allow her father to travel across the Kingdom to fulfill his responsibilities of combating the dead. But when her father is somehow trapped in Death, she must journey into the Old Kingdom to find him.

Our venue:


Yes! Mexican in the North End. Yummy!
results.name: Sabriel at Tenoch in the North End

WE ARE BACK AT TUFTS FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
Indoor Rock Gym:  Central Rock Gym Watertown Ma (Monday's)

This Meetup is for weekly climbing at the Central Rock Gym in Watertown, MA. This meetup is intended to provide climbing partners for both lead and top rope climbers that sign up for the meetups.

Meet by the cubbies facing the Lead Wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (Lovey) am usually wearing a teal harness with green & black climbing shoes.  Climb for 1.5 to 3 hrs. Adults of all skill levels and ages welcomed.  

**If you are leading, you should have your own rope. Work it out with your partner as to whose rope you'll be using if only one rope will be used between the two of you. Sometimes lead climbers prefer to lead on their own rope so both lead climbers may bring their own ropes to use. Word of caution: other climbers may help themselves to the second rope when it's not in use.


**If you come late, come find me or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Mondays and can help you find the group. 

**There is another meetup group (and perhaps a second) that also climbs Watertown Mondays nights. If you miss the RSVP deadline, would appreciate a courtesy email/call to let me know you'll be joining us so I know to expect you.


**You are required to fill out the rock gym waivers. Go to their website http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php and fill out their Liability Waiver online to save time when you arrive at the gym. 

**It is your responsibility to make sure you have taken the CRG Belay and/or Lead tests. If you have never climbed at CRG, you will be required to take their Belay test given by their staff only. Please make certain to come a bit early to allow for time to take their belay test.

**If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the "Intro Belay Class". You can sign up for this class (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

**If you are interested in taking their Intro To Leading Climbing class, you can sign up for it at (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

Equipment required: harness, shoes, chalk and belay device. 


Day Passes - $20 (Student/Military: $16)

10-Day Punch card $180 (Student/Military: $144)


Gear Rental:

- $8 Full Package

- $5 Harness

- $5 Shoes

- $2 Chalk

- $2 Belay Device

Membership options and further details are available on the website:http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php

=============================================

Waiver:  Read !!!

Be Warned!

Mountaineering, Skiing – Alpine or Back Country, Rock & Ice Climbing by its very nature is an extremely hazardous activity.

Falling off any part of an climbing route or bouldering challenge or other associated activities, even hiking to a destination may result in injury or death. Weather, Trail conditions be it a slip on a trail or falling objects like rocks, climbing gear or tree’s from above, or avalanche can all incur injuries and/or death. 

Any information on this Meetup group page is for the basic understanding of what could be encountered. We do not guarantee any type of accuracy on this information. Seek your own additional resources of information.  You as an active member! Perhaps, lacking any of the following: professional training, good judgment, moral character or a conscience. We or anyone on any Meetup-Mountaineers cannot be held responsible in anyway.

When arriving at any Meetup you should always use your own best judgment. You must decide whether or not the conditions “ both physical or mental” are in your best interests. 

You cannot blame the organizer(s) if you get hurt. To join this meetup event you must acknowledge that you have read this waiver and thereby you completely and totally agree to indemnify the organizer(s) from any possible legal action related to any type of illness, injury, loss of equipment etc. that might potentially occur. We are not guides or leaders in any event held. Just the organizers of finding a meeting location that people with similar interests can meet and socialize.

That said have fun! Play safely! And take the responsibility of your own actions.


The Organizers…

"Way out west there was this fella... fella I wanna tell ya about. Fella by the name of Jeff Lebowski."

What is The Big Lebowski, you say? Well, if you have to ask... not only is it one of the biggest and best cult movies of our time, but more importantly, this Coen Brothers classic is an outrageously insane comedy of bowling, confused identities, naked performance art, porn-obsessed nihilists, a sex offender named Jesus, and some unforgettable musical dream sequences - Oh, and some guy called "The Dude."

Our annual Big Lebowski Bowling Party has become one of our biggest Summer events! Not only do you get to see this fantastic film on the big screen, but we throw in plenty of pre-show festivities to really tie things together. There will be Lebowski trivia, a costume contest and of course bowling! We've collected a ton of Dude-themed prizes to hand out; so dust off your bathrobes, work on your Walter impressions, and come celebrate this cult sensation! (Just don't pee on our rugs, man.)

Doesn't get better than this, John

results.description:
Welcome to our regular meetup!  We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing board games -- specifically, the kind of board games that make you think.  We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.


This season, in addition to playing games, we will be raffling off a bunch of popular games!  There will be a raffle at each meetup.  Simply by showing up, you'll get a chance to win free games. The more often you come, the more entries you'll receive.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message ahead of time, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm until the last people leave (usually quite a few hours).

Our group has been running since 2007, and at this point we have a pretty large crowd of regulars.  A lot of people come once every few weeks, and RSVPs are appreciated but not required, so the RSVP list is often smaller than our actual attendance.  We expect about 30-45 people at most of our meetups.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

People new to Euros are very welcome.  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); the heaviest strategy games (like 18xx or wargames); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (You will also receive extra raffle tickets any time you donate.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block away from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza.  We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot).  When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Monday Game Night + Giveaway

results.description:
From the Boston doorknockers: 

As we move into the third month of our project, we're putting on our third training for folks who want to participate in #blacklivesmatter doorknocking efforts.

This project arises out of a national call for white folks to organize other white folks to support the struggle against police brutality and oppression of Black people in general.

This space is ideal for veteran activists and new comers alike! We'll update you on the status of the project, share our goals, and create lots of time to practice and get comfortable talking one on one about racism, white supremacy, and the work being in Boston.

We will be meeting in the library of the YWCA in Cambridge - use the Bishop Allen entrance if you are able to use stairs.

Use the Temple St entrance and call[masked] when you arrive if you need elevator access.


Children are welcome! Contact us through posting, direct message, or [masked] if you have questions or specific needs.

This event is targeted at white allies, people of all races are welcome to participate.


Get the latest info via Facebook.
results.name: August #blacklivesmatter doorknocking training

results.description:
This is the first event in the library's annual Fall Concert Series.  


Cold Chocolate is creating an exciting and unique new sound in the world of Americana: fusing bluegrass and roots with a dash of funk. With original tunes and technical prowess, this four-piece band from Boston is rocking audiences with guitar, banjo, upright bass, drums, and four-part harmony.


Guitarist/songwriter Ethan Robbins began his bluegrass career at Oberlin College where he met upright bassist Kirsten Lamb and began to explore how this hard-driving fast-paced genre could be stretched. Now joined by the funk-inflected banjo of James McIver and the loose-wristed Ariel Bernstein on drums, Cold Chocolate has established itself as a force in the Americana genre.


Here's their website for a sample of their music:

http://www.coldchocolatemusic.com/

The event is in the library's Sutton Room.  We'll meet there.  Register beforehand at http://www.libraryinsight.net/calendarmv.asp?x=3&sm=&jx=pap&nMonth=8&nYear=2015
results.how_to_find_us: http://www.peabodylibrary.org/about/directions.html
results.name: Let's listen to the group Cold Chocolate @  Peabody Institute Library, Peabody

Our Free Networking will be at Grafton Street Pub & Grill as usual, at 1230 Mass Ave in Harvard Square. Walking distance from the T and plenty of parking!


Join a diverse group of entrepreneurs in the food business for a networking event! We have held a number of these already with great success. It's great to see how many business and personal relationships have resulted from these events.

Hope to see you there!!

Kim Courtney

results.description:
Android developers get together for informal discussion of mobile technologies. Everyone is welcome, all interests and skill levels. 


Stop by to talk about the mobile industry, debug some Android code, or hang out with other techies and coders. There is free WiFi. We will meet in the lounge area of the bar. You can get a drink or food from the bar & lounge menu. You might bring a laptop to this group if you have some code to talk about. I will have mine!

This is a double meetup brought to you by the Boston GDG and Boston Android.


See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Green Line, Arlington Station, walk from Downtown Crossings

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
